Fiji’s Ministry of Education has issued a statement to say that all schools nationwide will remain closed.  Schools will re-open for face-to-face classes and classroom teaching when we are once again COVID-contained.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210531131741/https://www.fijitimes.com/covid-19-schools-will-remain-closed-until-fiji-is-covid-contained-moe/

Authorities have tightened regulations on businesses in Fiji amid ongoing COVID-19 concerns. Under the latest measures, all companies that wish to operate must limit capacity to 50 percent; capacity limits do not apply to manufacturing facilities where additional employees are required.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210531132057/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/481511/fiji-authorities-tightening-restrictions-for-businesses-nationwide-as-of-may-21-due-to-covid-19-concerns-update-6

Religious and other public gatherings are banned, though funerals may take place with up to 20 people.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210531132057/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/481511/fiji-authorities-tightening-restrictions-for-businesses-nationwide-as-of-may-21-due-to-covid-19-concerns-update-6

https://web.archive.org/web/20210531132057/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/481511/fiji-authorities-tightening-restrictions-for-businesses-nationwide-as-of-may-21-due-to-covid-19-concerns-update-6  The government continues to impose tighter measures on Viti Levu where COVID-19 transmission is occurring. An 18:00-04:00 curfew remains in effect islandwide. Officials have extended a lockdown in the Nadali area of Nausori until early June to enable widespread testing. Residents must stay home, except for emergencies, and cannot exit the town. Returning individuals can enter Nadali but cannot leave again.

The government has offered a tax and tariff reductions, and loan repayment holidays (up to F$ 400 million (USD 188.64) of the total envelope) aim at protecting public health, supporting the economy and ensuring food security. A second fiscal package was announced as part of the FY2020-21 budget for the fiscal year beginning in August. The stimulus mainly consists of sizeable tax and tariff cuts. Fiscal and import excise duties on over 1,600 items were reduced or eliminated.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210531135356/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

There is a mask mandate in some public spaces across the country. Employers must ensure that employees and customers wear appropriate protective equipment, including facemasks, check temperature checks before entry, and consistently enforce 2-meter (6.5-foot) distancing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210803172611/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/506836/fiji-authorities-implementing-1800-0400-curfew-in-viti-levu-as-of-july-28-update-9

As of June 2,  Fiji has vaccinated 163,364 individuals with their first dose of the vaccine, 31% of the target population in people aged 18 and older. The vaccination programme is expected to accelerate and reach all the divisions and sub-divisions as more vaccines are received from COVAX and pledged donations from the governments of Australia and New Zealand.  In addition, individuals who received the first dose of AstraZeneca Covishield vaccine from 5th to 16th April 2021 and are due to receive the second dose between 7th June to 25th June 2021, can go to the nearest vaccination sites. The dose interval period of 8-12 weeks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004045908/https://www.who.int/nauru/news/detail/02-06-2021-fiji-intensifies-covid-19-response-efforts  https://web.archive.org/web/20210603011909/https://www.health.gov.fj/covid-19-vaccination-campaign/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211004050328/https://www.health.gov.fj/second-dose-of-covid-19-vaccine-rolled-out/
All vaccines administered are provided as a part of the COVAX initiative and free to the public    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614193410/https://www.health.gov.fj/covid-vaccine/vaccine-faqs/

Most public places in Viti Levu are closed, other than essential businesses including supermarkets and pharmacies.   The capital, Suva is part of a large containment area reaching to Nausori where restrictions are in place. Some non-essential businesses have resumed operations alongside essential businesses following approval from government provided that they follow COVID-19 safety protocols.     https://archive.vn/G61dg
The Fijian government is encouraging most people to work from home, and to leave their houses only if essential.    https://archive.vn/G61dg
Public transportation within the zones is available but limited to 50 percent seating capacity.     https://archive.vn/G61dg

The Fijian government is encouraging most people to work from home, and to leave their houses only if essential. A nationwide curfew is in effect from 6pm to 4am each night.    https://archive.vn/G61dg
Scheduled international and domestic passenger flights have been suspended though some outbound “Special flights” are being operated by Fiji Airways.     https://archive.vn/G61dg

On August 12, 2021, the Fiji government begins priority for Moderna COVID-19 vaccines to the following group of high risk individuals:  - Pregnant women;  - Individuals aged 60 years and above;  - Persons with comorbid issues such as hypertension, asthma, chronic lung disease, cardiac disease, severe obesity, diabetes, liver disease;  - Persons with Rheumatic Heart Disease; and  - Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection and persons with disability.    As of July 20th, a total of 401,404 Fijians or 68.4% of the target population have received their first dose of the AstraZeneca vaccine, while 80,895 people (13.8%) have received both jabs.  The government is urging encouraging residents and especially those in the above high risk groups to get the Moderna vaccine after record daily infections and deaths recorded. Fiji will begin administering the Moderna vaccine after more than 150,000 doses of the vaccine arrived in Fiji through the US government and the COVAX Facility.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004050633/https://www.fiji.gov.fj/Media-Centre/News/MODERNA-COVID-19-VACCINE-PRIORITY-GROUPS-FOR-VITI  https://web.archive.org/web/20211004050937/https://www.rnz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/447293/fijians-urged-to-vaccinate-as-moderna-arrives  https://web.archive.org/web/20211004020435/https://www.health.gov.fj/covid-vaccine/vaccine-faqs/
All vaccines administered are provided as a part of the COVAX initiative and free to the public    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614193410/https://www.health.gov.fj/covid-vaccine/vaccine-faqs/
No explicit change in policy but daily media releases no longer report contact tracing numbers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210914225615/https://www.health.gov.fj/23-08-2021/

Travel restrictions have been in place in Fiji following a COVID-19 outbreak. Scheduled international and domestic passenger flights have been suspended though some outbound “Special flights” are being operated by Fiji Airways. The main island of Viti Levu has two “containment zones” one covering the Greater Suva Area and one covering the Nadi/Lautoka area in the west. Travel into and out of these zones is restricted. The Fijian Government continues with targeted of lockdown of areas where existing clusters of COVID-19 exist. Some boat services to and from Viti Levu remain suspended but some journeys have been approved under tight controls.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004210351/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/fiji/coronavirus

The maintenance of contact tracing records and is required and use of careFIJI app is mandatory.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210531142411/https://www.mcttt.gov.fj/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/Fijian-COVID-Safe-Economic-Recovery-Framework_-Rev-3.pdf

On September 20, the Fiji government begins administering Moderna vaccination rollouts to school clusters with all four divisions. These vaccines will be administered to students age 15 to 17 years old. Vaccinations for those 12 to 14  year olds will be announced at a later date.  As of Sep 16, 580,504 Fijians, or 97.7 % of adults in Fiji have received their first dose of a COVID-19 vaccine and 372,434 or 63.5% have received their second dose.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004051956/https://www.health.gov.fj/vaccine-for-children/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211004052051/https://www.health.gov.fj/children-15-17/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211004020435/https://www.health.gov.fj/covid-vaccine/vaccine-faqs/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211004052139/https://www.health.gov.fj/covid-19-vaccination-campaign/
vaccines free of charge.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211004052051/https://www.health.gov.fj/children-15-17/
From 4 October onwards, children ages 15+ in schools are also being vaccinated.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211004052051/https://www.health.gov.fj/children-15-17/
vaccines free of charge.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211004052051/https://www.health.gov.fj/children-15-17/

containment zone restrictions have been lifted on Viti Levu, but remain in effect for other islands; nationwide curfew from 11 p.m. to 4 a.m.; source: /web/20211105154639/https://fj.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Fiji Airways has resumed regularly scheduled flights; effective November 8 all non-citizen, nonimmigrant airline passengers must demonstrate proof of vaccination; fully vaccinated travelers will continue to be required to show a pre-departure negative test taken within three (3) days of travel; to further strengthen protections, unvaccinated travelers will now need to test within one (1) day of departure; visitors to Fiji and Fijian citizens are required to quarantine for up to three days; /web/20211105154639/https://fj.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

PCR and/or antigen tests available; test results available within 72 hours; tests must be taken within 3 days of travel; source: /web/20211105154639/https://fj.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Government will roll out the digital VAX-Check tool which will be made available to all workplaces, tertiary institutions, houses of worship, hotels, restaurants, cafés, cinemas, gyms, pools and tattoo parlours allowing them to open at 70 per cent capacity but only to fully-vaccinated persons.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220228171934/https://www.fijitimes.com.fj/state-to-roll-out-vax-check-tool/

From tomorrow, informal gatherings in homes, communities, and community halls will be limited to 20 persons.    This is according to a statement released by the Minister for Commerce, Trade, Tourism and Transport, Faiyaz Koya.    He added that other venues which have been approved to operate under COVID-safe measures and or which require Care Fiji Commitment certification, including places of worship and restaurants, can host events, including weddings and other functions, at 80 percent capacity. However, other event venues seeking to host functions, but which do not have formal approval or certification to host events, must become Care Fiji Commitment certified to do so.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220207070654/https://www.fijitimes.com/covid-19-informal-gatherings-limited-to-20-persons-in-homes-communities-and-community-halls/

All Public Service Vehicles MUST operate at 80 percent capacity and ensure that all passengers are wearing masks. Interisland vessels must also operate at 80 percent capacity and ensure that all passengers must wear masks.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207070654/https://www.fijitimes.com/covid-19-informal-gatherings-limited-to-20-persons-in-homes-communities-and-community-halls/

The nationwide daily curfew from 12am to 4am has been completely lifted beginning from tonight.    Attorney-General Aiyaz Sayed-Khaiyum made the announcement in a press conference this afternoon.    Mr Sayed-Khaiyum said the curfew will not be moved nor shifted but lifted completely.    He said curfew was implemented to prevent non-essential gatherings that can spread the COVID-19 virus and allow for reliable contact tracing at certain hours in the evening.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207072252/https://www.fijitimes.com/nationwide-curfew-completely-lifted/

'On March 2, 2020, Naalakkersuisut approved the inclusion of COVID-19 (Corona Virus Disease 2019) disease on list A of Dangerous Diseases' and 'Landslægen website contains general recommendations for routines for how to prevent infection with airways in the airways.'    https://web.archive.org/web/20200506114445/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/03/0303_Coronavirus

'President of Naalakkersuisut Kim Kielsen and Chairman of the Epidemic Commission Police Chief Bjørn Tegner Bay invited a press conference on Thursday, March 12, 2020. [...] All assemblies with 100 people are strongly discouraged so far. In addition, it is strongly recommended that all indoor assemblies in buildings with public access be no larger than half the number of persons for which the building area is approved by the fire authorities.'  Effects coming into place 13th March.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200506114947/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/03/120320-Nye-anbefalinger-der-skal-forhindre-hurtig-smittespredning-af-coronavirus

Government press release on 12th March (with effects coming into place 13th March):   'It is strongly recommended that the number of passengers in city buses and other larger buses be limited to the number of passengers that can be seated.'  No closures, but restrictions on numbers.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200506114947/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/03/120320-Nye-anbefalinger-der-skal-forhindre-hurtig-smittespredning-af-coronavirus

In a press conference on 12th March, with effects coming into place on 13th March: 'All non-strictly necessary flights within Greenland are strongly discouraged so far.'  https://web.archive.org/web/20200506114947/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/03/120320-Nye-anbefalinger-der-skal-forhindre-hurtig-smittespredning-af-coronavirus

On the 13th March, the Danish Government closed off the borders to non-Danish citizens who do not have a recognized purpose for entering the Danish Realm including Greenland and the Faroe Islands.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200506093155/https://visitgreenland.com/articles/corona-virus-status/

"The first case is detected in Greenland. The infected person lives in Nuuk and is placed in home isolation. Cohabitants of the infected person have been placed under home quarantine."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200803161546/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/03/1603_foerste

Limited contact tracing is taking place for the few cases that currently exist in Greenland: "The first case is detected in Greenland. The infected person lives in Nuuk and is placed in home isolation. Cohabitants of the infected person have been placed under home quarantine." https://web.archive.org/web/20200803161546/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/03/1603_foerste

Closures of pubs, bars, and clubs are closed, restaurants and cafes only allowed to offer take away, and businesses that involve close contact with customers are closed.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200506134612/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/03/190320-Nye-tiltag-mod-spredning-af-COVID_19-i-Nuuk

Greenland introduced a range of measures on 18 March, including a ban on all public and private events with more than 10 people. Provisionally this was meant to cease at 8 April, but was extended.  See: http://web.archive.org/web/20200426151148/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/03/190320-Nye-tiltag-mod-spredning-af-COVID_19-i-Nuuk

Greenland announced that 'with effect from 18 March 2020 at. 16.00 - a temporary ban on holding or attending events, events, activities or the like where more than 10 people are gathered'. This does 'not not apply in private homes. However, it is strongly encouraged to cancel scheduled private gatherings, etc. with more than 10 people' and the police have the ' opportunity to intervene in public places if more than 10 people'.     https://web.archive.org/web/20200506134612/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/03/190320-Nye-tiltag-mod-spredning-af-COVID_19-i-Nuuk

Greenland introduced a range of measures on 18 March, but these did not include a requirement to stay at home. They do encourage people to stay at home, particularly if they have recently returned from overseas or have symptoms.  See: http://web.archive.org/web/20200426151148/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/03/190320-Nye-tiltag-mod-spredning-af-COVID_19-i-Nuuk

No citizens can leave the capital centre of Nuuk, which is where Greenland's recorded cases are. Travel is also strongly advised against in other regions.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200426151148/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/03/190320-Nye-tiltag-mod-spredning-af-COVID_19-i-Nuuk

Greenland introduced a range of measures on 18 March, but these did not include a requirement to stay at home. They do encourage people to stay at home, particularly if they have recently returned from overseas or have symptoms. This includes the elderly  See: http://web.archive.org/web/20200426151148/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/03/190320-Nye-tiltag-mod-spredning-af-COVID_19-i-Nuuk

Schools are closed nationwide: "All educational institutions and private as well as public day care institutions in Nuuk will be closed. Emergency care is provided."   https://web.archive.org/web/20200803153234/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/03/1803_tiltag_begraensninger

"Package to support employees in private companies:  107 DKK million has been set aside to compensate for wage costs for the employees in Greenland that private companies choose to send home instead of dismissing as a result of the COVID-19 situation."    Later announcements confirm that the wage costs provided by the government to private companies are 75% of wages, but are later increased to 90%.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200803170318/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/03/2103_Hjaelpepakker    https://web.archive.org/web/20200803171134/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/04/2304_Loenkompensation
Complete contact tracing done for confirmed cases.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200803163259/https://arctic-council.org/en/news/coronavirus-in-the-arctic-it-is-imperative-to-keep-the-virus-out/

The SMS will encourage you to follow our advice - keep your distance and wash your hands frequently - because it slows down the spread of infection.'    https://web.archive.org/web/20200506123325/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/03/2603_sms

On April 14, the education will gradually start for primary schools outside Nuuk and in all the educational institutions of the country under special instructions (with guidelines). Daycare centres and primary schools in Nuuk to open from Monday 20th, due to the success of opening outside of Nuuk.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200629103101/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/04/1704_institutioner

Naalakkersuisoq Karl Frederik Danielsen announced that from 25 April at 8 am, 'Recommendation for meetings of a maximum of 100 persons'    https://web.archive.org/web/20200506142525/https://www.nun.gl/Nyheder_COVID19/2020/04/2204_Groenland_aabner_op_i_to_faser?sc_lang=da

As Greenland begins to ease restrictions, public transit resumes. International travel still restricted.   http://archive.vn/wip/jOZwP

Testing strategy is widened to make testing compulsory for all entrants to Greenland:  "The test strategy is as follows:  - All entrants from Denmark to Greenland are tested for COVID-19 before departure, followed by a 14-day quarantine on arrival at the destination.  - On the 5th day upon arrival, all travelers to cities must be tested for coronavirus at the local health center or regional hospital.  If the destination is a settlement, only the quarantine rules apply. If you have the opportunity to be quarantined for 5 days in the nearest town before leaving for your village, the test can take place there. Testing in settlements fraset in Kangerlussuaq cannot be performed.  All entrants and citizens with symptoms, and who have had or have contact with entrants, will be able to be tested.  Selected patient groups who do not belong to a risk group for infection, but who have symptoms of COVID-19 infection, will to a limited extent also be offered testing. This is carried out as part of the monitoring of Covid-19 in Greenland."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200803163020/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/05/0305_teststrategi

Office of Medical Officer of Health maintains that schools are open across the country with safety measures in place (since an executive order was issued on 29 May) - website updated 11 June)  "Teaching is normal for primary schools throughout the country and in all the country's educational institutions under special instruction that takes into account:  as much space as possible around the pupils / students; Among other things, by utilizing all the school institution's areas, maximum utilization of the school day, etc.  that all advice on hygiene is observed as far as possible: physical distance, hand hygiene, hand alcohol.  that canteen - restaurant meets the requirements of shops"  http://archive.fo/tkZEq

With Greenland opening, only those home-quarantining are asked to remain home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200616031705/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/06/120620-Genaabning-den-15_-juni-fastholdes

"In connection with the reopening, it is important that everyone in Greenland follows: - The health professional advice - The rules of entry - Home quarantine rules The health advice is: - Keep distance - Wash hands frequently and use handshake - Cough or sneeze in the sleeve  Travelers from Denmark must: - Be tested negative 2-5 days before departure - Filling in the Sumut form - When you come to Greenland you must go directly into the home quarantine - On the 5th day of your home quarantine, re-test for Covid-19  If your re-test is negative, your quarantine will end If your test is positive - your home insulation will begin, and your GP will contact you about your new precautions  For home quarantine: - That you should stay in your home as far as possible - You may want to go out, but avoid contact with other people - keep away  Home quarantine does not apply to the other household if you can avoid close physical contact and focus on good hygiene."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200616031730/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/06/120620-Genaabning-den-15_-juni-fastholdes

Translated:  "It is now possible to hold public events within current municipal boundaries with certain restrictions. It is the organizer's responsibility to ensure that there is no participation from persons from other municipalities or that they are encouraged to do so.  The purpose of the adaptations is to meet the desire for permission to organize events at the same time as the desire to minimize the risk of infection spread, it is stated."    News link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20200628151606/https://sermitsiaq.ag/nye-regler-private-offentlige-arrangementer  Official announcement (in Danish):  https://naalakkersuisut.gl/~/media/Nanoq/Files/Kundgoerelser/DK/2020/Bekendtgoerelser/Selvstyrets%20bekendtgrelse%20nr%2021%20af%2019%20juni%202020%20da.pdf

Updated guidance on testing maintains existing guidelines on testing policy:  "Guidelines for corona tests in Greenland  For citizens in Greenland  Citizens with symptoms who have had or have contact with entrants will be able to be tested  Selected patient groups who do not belong to a risk group for infection, but who have symptoms of COVID-19 infection, will to a limited extent also be offered testing. This is carried out as part of the monitoring of COVID-19 in Greenland"  http://archive.fo/mncES    Coding as 2, as the clause for 1 (both symptomatic and contact with entrants) as well as 2 (testing for symptomatic groups, albeit limited to some extent) are being met

The government's 'Entry to Greenland' page archived on August 10th was "updated on the 21st of July", which is the date the "Self-Government Executive Order no. 26 of 20 July 2020 on conditions for entry to Greenland (Phase 2)" came into effect.   The code has changed from 1G to 0 on July 21st because there are no further restrictions, required or recommended, on internal movement, for those who aren't recent entrants to Greenland.  However, the Executive Order describes required quarantine upon arrival into Greenland and related restrictions on internal movement "before it is considered proven that they [entrants to Greenland] are not infected with Covid-19". This movement restriction is specifically an international travel policy and therefore accounted for under international travel restrictions. C8-2 shows there is a quarantine policy in place.  "Your trip depends on your final destination   If you have passed a negative COVID-19 test before departure and filled in the SUMUT form, you can travel to the following cities without further restrictions.   The 10 towns and two villages are:   Municipality of Sermersooq   - Nuuk   - Paamiut   Qeqqata Municipality   - Sisimiut   - Maniitsoq   - Kangerlussuaq   Municipality Kujalleq   - Qaqortoq   - Narsaq   - Narsarsuaq   Municipality Qeqertalik   - Aasiaat   - Qasigiannguit   - Qeqertarsuaq   Avannaata Municipality   - Ilulissat   If your final destination is not figuerer above list you   Stay in the city with health center that is closest to your final destination.   If you have a home address in Greenland, you can contact the authorities regarding accommodation facilities for test results.   If you do not have an address in your final destination, you must maintain the expenses that may be associated with overnight stays, rebookings, board and lodging.   Contact your local health center and order a COVID-19 test to be performed at 5 p.m.   In the event of a negative test result, you can travel on to your final destination.   3. In the event of a positive result, you must go directly into isolation. The health center will contact the National Board of Health for further clarification of your situation."   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200810150502/https://nun.gl/Emner/Borgere/Coronavirus_emne/Rejser_til_Groenland_fra_den_15_juni?sc_lang=da  (Entry to Greenland page) & http://web.archive.org/web/20201110102927/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/~/media/Nanoq/Files/Kundgoerelser/DK/2020/Bekendtgoerelser/Selvstyrets%20bekendtgrelse%20nr%2026%20af%2020%20juli%202020%20om%20betingelser%20for%20indrejse%20til%20Grnland%20Fase%202%20da.pdf (Executive Order)

Since July 21, travellers were not required to self-quarantine upon arrival in Greenland or re-test for COVID-19 after arrival. See: https://dk.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/ (web archive link not working)

Weekly update of Danish list of ’open and banned countries’, applies to entry into Greenland as well. Entrants from banned countries can only enter under certain conditions e.g. if they are employed or are students in the country.     Banned European countries now include : Belgium, Bulgaria, Malta, Luxembourg, Romania, Spain. Belgium, Spain, Malta are new additions since the update from the previous week on 30 July.  Countries other than EU Member States, Schengen countries and the United Kingdom are currently by definition 'banned' countries, with the following exceptions: Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, and Uruguay.    https://web.archive.org/save/https://politi.dk/en/coronavirus-in-denmark/travelling-in-or-out-of-denmark/is-my-country-open-or-banned
Denmark has only reopened its borders for international tourism, allowing in both EU nations and a few select countries outside of the EU to now visit.

Executive Order nr 37 from 29 September regarding travelling to and in Greenland is valid from 30 September 2020 through 31 January 2021.    Entrance requirements:  - Upon check-in one must show a maximum 5 day old negative Corona test.  - They must also show a confirmation of the completed Sumut form, a personal locator form, which advises where you will be visiting and whom you will come in contact with. This form can be downloaded at www.sumut2020.    Due to the high Reproduction factor in Denmark and other countries, the earlier quarantine rules are now back in effect. This means that all travellers upon arrival in Greenland must:    - go into 14 days quarantine if you are not re-tested in Greenland.  - go into quarantine until receipt of a negative re-test result, which can be first conducted on day 5 after arrival.    https://web.archive.org/save/https://visitgreenland.com/articles/corona-virus-status/

In Greenland, you are required to wear a bandage(mask) in the following situations:    1. For international and domestic flights.  This applies to everyone over the age of 12 as well as the cabin crew, with a few exceptions when on the plane, staying at airports or terminal areas.  When employed with passenger contact in terminal areas and the like, you must wear a bandage or visor if a plastic screen cannot be set up between employees and travelers. Reference is also made to § 6 and § 7 Self-Government Executive Order no. 37 of 29 September 2020 on conditions for travel to and in Greenland  2. If you are infected or at risk of being infected with a new coronavirus and exceptionally have to move out, eg because you need to be tested.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201006064205/https://nun.gl/emner/borgere/coronavirus_emne/rejser_til_groenland_fra_den_15_juni?sc_lang=da

The Ministry of Business and Labor released “Guidelines of September 2020 establishing detailed criteria for application, award and administration of funds under the labor market package”   “Wage costs must:…B. relate to the period 19 March 2020 - 30 September 2020, both days inclusive.” No policies which have extended the period of wage costs beyond September 30th have been found.  “3. Compensation is limited to salary expenses for the following employees  A. Employees with a permanent connection to the company. Firm affiliation means that there must be an employment contract between employee and company for the company to receive salary compensation for the employee. The agreement must have been entered into before 19 March 2020.  Loose workers are not covered as they do not have a permanent affiliation with the company. Loose workers are characterized by the employment is only very short-lived so that the employment is terminated when e.g. day work is over and the employee is not committed to work the following day. The employment relationship must have one duration exceeding 2 days. The employment must be permanent”  “The compensation is calculated as follows:  A. 90% of the salary expense, however, a maximum of DKK 20,190, per 30 days wage compensation period per. employee.   B. If the wage compensation period is shorter than 30 days, is calculated compensation as a proportionate share rounded to nearest whole day.  C. Deducting any other support from public funds to the applicant concerning the same wage cost.”   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201019212330/https://www.businessingreenland.gl/~/media/Erhverv/COVID-19/30%20september/DK%20Retningslinjer%20vedr%20arbejdsmarkedspakke%20pr%2030%20september%202020.pdf?la=da

There have been no updates to Greenland’s testing guidelines for citizens, on The Office of the Medical Director of Health website, since August 20, 2020.   It remains the case:  “Citizens with symptoms who have had or have contact with entrants will be able to be tested  Selected patient groups who do not belong to a risk group for infection, but who have symptoms of COVID-19 infection, will to a limited extent also be offered testing. This is carried out as part of the monitoring of COVID-19 in Greenland.”  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201108232920/https://www.nun.gl/emner/borgere/coronavirus_emne/hvem_bliver_testet_for_covid_19?sc_lang=da

Visit Greenland’s Q&A response to ‘Who can enter Greenland’ is “Travellers with residence in the following countries have conditional permission to travel to the Kingdom of Denmark, including Greenland – see here. The numbers are re-evaluated on a weekly basis, and therefore a country’s status can change between open and closed. There is no longer a limit on how many persons may arrive to Greenland.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201108215641/https://visitgreenland.com/corona-faq/  A hyperlink followed by pressing “see here” went to a coronavirus site ran by the Danish Authorities which had a    “List of high-risk countries within the EU and the Schengen area as well as the United Kingdom applicable from 7 November 2020 00.00 (in Danish)  Countries/regions added to the list of banned countries  Innlandet, Norway?Oslo, Norway?Vestland, Norway?Viken, Norway?Västerbotten, Sweden?Västernorrland, Sweden?Estonia”   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201108215839/https://coronasmitte.dk/en/entry-into-denmark/is-my-country-open-or-banned  Also, “From Monday 9 November, the airspace over Greenland will be closed and therefore there can only be approach to Greenland from Copenhagen Airport. Certain types of flights are excluded, such as emergency flights.” “The increased control over the entrance to Greenland is taking place as an additional measure to protect Greenland in relation to the Corona infection. It is the Self-Government that has asked the Danish authorities to close the airspace in order to have gathered all travelers in one place and thus ensure that everyone is subjected to the same control and test, as well as information. It is not yet known how long the closure will last.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201108220102/https://www.nun.gl/nyheder_covid19/2020/11/0611_kun-en-indgang-til-groenland?sc_lang=da

Policy remains unchanged. Test available to anyone with symptoms.     Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221152615/https://nun.gl/emner/borgere/coronavirus_emne/hvem_bliver_testet_for_covid_19?sc_lang=da

Updated restrictions to forbid travel to/from Denmark as well as all other regions. 'Based on the health professional recommendations and forecasts for potential spread of infection in society, the Naalakkersuisut has actively looked at reducing the number of travellers over Christmas and the New Year... The departures to and from Denmark on 21 and 22 December will be canceled as well as associated domestic connections.' Possibly extended until January 17th.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221143722/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/12/0212_lukning_aflysning

Salary compensation may be granted for the period 1 January 2021 to 30 June 2021. To qualify, claimants must work for a company capable of documenting a loss of turnover of at least 30% in 2020 compared to 2019 and the majority of workers for said company must be resident in Greenland.  Salary compensation is set at 90% of wage below a cap of DKK 20,190, per calendar month.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210209232639/https://www.businessingreenland.gl/~/media/Groenlands%20Erhvervsportal/Files/Hjaelpepakker%202021/DK%20Retningslinjer%20for%20arbejdsmarkedspakke%20pr%2029012021.pdf?la=da

Greenland government announced the priority groups on 3rd Jan 2021. The priority groups are  All citizens aged 75 and over.  Residents of retirement homes (regardless of age).  Employees in old people's homes, in home help and selected groups in the health care system who all have extensive patient contact in their work.  Persons in special risk groups (selected by the health service)    https://web.archive.org/web/20210116204616/https://nun.gl/nyheder_covid19/2021/01/0301_de-foerste-vacciner?sc_lang=da

A,B,C:  * citizens over the age of 75  * residents of retirement homes  * employees in old people's homes, in home care and selected groups in the health care system who all have extensive patient contact in their work  * persons in special risk groups (selected by the health service)    http://web.archive.org/web/20210126131939/https://nun.gl/emner/borgere/coronavirus_emne/covid_19_vaccination?sc_lang=da    Greenland received about 1,000 doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine from Denmark for inoculation in Nuuk and Illulissat.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210111231603/https://www.rcinet.ca/eye-on-the-arctic/2021/01/04/greenland-launches-covid-19-vaccination-campaign-1/

The priority groups started to receive the vaccines on 4th Jan.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210126131939/https://nun.gl/emner/borgere/coronavirus_emne/covid_19_vaccination?sc_lang=da  http://web.archive.org/web/20210111231603/https://www.rcinet.ca/eye-on-the-arctic/2021/01/04/greenland-launches-covid-19-vaccination-campaign-1/  https://archive.vn/w00tq  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315231014/https://www.rcinet.ca/eye-on-the-arctic/2021/01/04/greenland-launches-covid-19-vaccination-campaign-1/

Means of transport must not carry more passengers than there are seats. The obligation of compliance rests with the owner of the means of transport.    https://archive.fo/GAYju

A, B. Here’s how the doses were distributed: Geographically (Nuuk – 903 doses; Ilulissat – 402 doses), By population (Frontline health care staff – 396; Frontline nursing home staff – 133; Nursing home residents, seniors and those with prior health conditions – 776). Greenland received the Pfizer/BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine.    https://archive.vn/w00tq
No restrictions on public transport.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329182545/https://nun.gl/

Vaccinations (Pfizer/BioNTech) have been carried out in the main cities of entry, namely Nuuk, Ilulissat, Aasiaat, Sisimiut and Qaqortoq. The target groups have been everyone aged 65 and over, health and care workers, as well as people who are medically assessed to be at particular risk of serious illness. A successful co-operation project with the Arctic Command has also been carried out, where vaccinations have been carried out in Qeqertarsuatsiaat and Paamiut.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329104455/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2021/03/2603_Vaccine    https://web.archive.org/web/20210329105554/https://covid19.trackvaccines.org/country/greenland/

No policy change. Recommended hygiene and safety measures, including staying at home as much as possible.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210329112703/https://www.nun.gl/emner/borgere/1_kopi_af_coronavirus_emne/sundhed_og_risikogrupper/risikogrupper_og_saerligt_saarbare?sc_lang=da

Greenland updated its vaccination programme on 26th Mar 2021:  'In the coming months, the goal is to start vaccinations in North, East and South Greenland as well as in the remaining towns and villages in West Greenland. The following principles will be used:  In those parts of North, East and South Greenland that have limited connections, everyone aged 18 and older will have to be vaccinated at the same time. The same will apply in all settlements throughout the country.  In the cities in West Greenland where vaccination has not yet begun, everyone aged 50 and over will initially be offered vaccination.  Eventually, the younger age groups in the cities will be offered vaccination.'    https://web.archive.org/web/20210329104455/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2021/03/2603_Vaccine

Sectors are open with restrictions.  Restaurants and cafes are open. For indoor dining, you will need to have a ‘corona pass’ (full vaccination, a negative test taken within 72 hours, a positive test taken between 14 days and 12 weeks ago). Travelers must also present a negative COVID-19 PCR test result taken no more than 72 hours prior to travel into Greenland.  If you have been vaccinated, you no longer need to be quarantined at home on arrival in Greenland, nor do you need to take a re-test after arrival. It should also be noted that you must still have performed a covid-19 test before entry. Travelers who are not fully vaccinated must quarantine for five days prior to taking their test. Travelers are not cleared to leave quarantine until receiving a negative COVID-19 test in Greenland.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210718112618/https://dk.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210718112924/https://corona.nun.gl/emner/til_den_rejsende/indrejse_til_groenland?sc_lang=da

From 5 August, there are additional gathering restrictions in Sisimiut, Upernavik, Upernavik district and Aasiaat. No new policies found about income support. However, upon backtracking, saw this note made on 01 Jan 2021 and said that support may be granted until 30 June 2021:    Salary compensation may be granted for the period 1 January 2021 to 30 June 2021. To qualify, claimants must work for a company capable of documenting a loss of turnover of at least 30% in 2020 compared to 2019 and the majority of workers for said company must be resident in Greenland.  Salary compensation is set at 90% of wage below a cap of DKK 20,190, per calendar month.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210209232639/https://www.businessingreenland.gl/~/media/Groenlands%20Erhvervsportal/Files/Hjaelpepakker%202021/DK%20Retningslinjer%20for%20arbejdsmarkedspakke%20pr%2029012021.pdf?la=da

You’ll find the latest official announcement *here.  -Certain rules may apply only to specific cities or areas. E.g. local restrictions regarding face masks or access to public localities. Please find information about any current local restrictions *here. Please note that the page might be in Danish.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212154457/https://corona.nun.gl/en/at-the-workplace/suliffeqarfimmi-malittarisassat-2-3/    *Area restrictions  These dwellings are currently contagious from unknown sources of infection and therefore subject to special restrictions: Nuuk, Qasigiannguit, Upernavik, Tasiusaq, Upernavik Kujalleq, Nutaarmiut, Nuussuaq, Innaarsuit, Naajaat, Aappilattoq, Kangersuatsiaq, Kullorsuaq.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212154716/https://corona.nun.gl/da/omraderestriktioner/    They also had to update their website tab from 'At the workplace' to becoming 'Business'.

In Greenland, there is a requirement for vaccination against COVID-19 or a negative PCR test, which is a maximum of 48 hours old, for people who want to stay in premises and associated areas with public access.  -You are only allowed access to the following places if you are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 or have a negative PCR test that is a maximum of 48 hours old:  1) Restaurants, cafes, pubs, discos and similar establishments and their adjoining outdoor areas.  2) Cultural institutions, including culture centres, cinemas, museums, exhibition halls, etc.  3) Community centres and similar establishments.  4) Libraries.  5) Indoor and outdoor sports facilities, including sports colleges and sports halls, swimming pools, gyms, football pitches, etc.  6) Hairdressers, massage parlours, beauty clinics and similar establishments.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212155747/https://corona.nun.gl/en/corona-passport-digital-eu-covid-certificate/vaccination-as-a-requirement-for-access/

Domestic travel in Greenland:  -If you travel from a city or settlement to another place within the country’s borders, you must be fully vaccinated or have a negative test that is no more than 48 hours old at the time of departure.  -The owner of the means of transportation is responsible for ensuring that all travellers obey the rules.  -Unvaccinated people over the age of 2 years old traveling out of a city or settlement where it is not possible to be tested must quarantine at their destination for 14 days, or until they get a negative PCR test. If it is not possible to get a PCR test at the destination, they must quarantine for 14 days.  -If you are in quarantine, you are not allowed to attend events or gatherings. You may go and get tested and go to grocery stores to make necessary purchases if you wear face masks or visors.  -Children under the age of 2 are exempt from the requirement of showing documentation of a test.  -If you have previously been infected with COVID-19 within the last 12 weeks, and you are able to document this, the same rules apply to you as to fully vaccinated people.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212160622/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/domestic-travel-in-greenland/

In Greenland, there is a requirement that people aged 15 and older must be fully vaccinated if they want access to premises to which the public has access. Previously, a negative PCR test also gave access to such premises, but that is no longer possible.  -You must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19  -You are only allowed access to the following places if you are fully vaccinated against COVID-19:  1) Restaurants, cafes, pubs, discos and similar establishments.  2) Cultural institutions, including culture centres, cinemas, museums, exhibition halls, etc.  3) Community centres and similar establishments.  4) Libraries.  5) Indoor sports facilities, including sports colleges and sports halls, swimming pools, gyms, football pitches, etc.  6) Hairdressers, massage parlours, beauty clinics and similar establishments.  When are you fully vaccinated?  -People who have completed a full vaccination programme, for example two doses of Pfizer or Moderna vaccine or one dose of Johnson&Johnson vaccine, are considered fully vaccinated. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. This means that for the time being there is no requirement to get the booster vaccination to be considered fully vaccinated.  -If you have previously been infected with COVID-19 and can present documentation of a positive PCR test result which is between 14 days and 12 weeks old, you are covered by the same rules as if you were fully vaccinated.  *updated on 26Jan2022  https://web.archive.org/web/20211228235327/https://corona.nun.gl/en/corona-passport-digital-eu-covid-certificate/vaccination-as-a-requirement-for-access/

No advice regarding domestic travel.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211120171839/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/

Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated or a resident of Greenland or you are relocating to Greenland.    -In regard to entering Greenland, you are considered fully vaccinated 14 days after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. This means that for the time being there is no requirement to get the booster vaccination to be considered fully vaccinated.    When you intend to travel to Greenland, you must remember to do the following:  -You must have a negative COVID-19 PCR test from a Nordic country (Denmark, Sweden, Norway, Finland, Iceland, Faroe Islands), UK, Liechtenstein, Switzerland, or a country in EU that is maximum 48 hours old from the time of departure and have valid documentation showing this.  -Bring a face mask for the journey and wear it during the journey, on the plane and in the airport, and also during transport to your place of residence. This rule applies to everyone at 12 years old or older.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211220215011/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/conditions-for-entry-into-greenland/

Corona passport (digital EU COVID certificate)  -People in Greenland who have been vaccinated can get a corona passport.  -You can use a corona passport e.g. if you are travelling abroad and you need to document that you have been vaccinated against COVID-19. In some countries, you must show your corona passport or documentation of previous infection upon arrival.  https://archive.vn/lWkU1    Area restrictions  -There is no longer an inventory of cities and settlements with spread of infection from unknown sources. Restrictions regarding use of face masks and maximum occupancy of establishments apply to the entire country with exception of Ittoqqortoormiit and Tasiilaq, as well as the settlements Kulusuk, Isortoq, Kuummiut, Sermiligaaq and Tiniteqilaaq. The executive order is published on Naalakkersuisut’s announcement portal. Current restrictions are also explained in detail on the various pages at corona.nun.gl  https://archive.vn/Bp0OH    *updated guidelines and restrictions since 04 Feb 2022

“As of midnight this morning, it has become possible to implement measures as a Designated Infectious Disease, including hospitalization for the patients infected by the novel coronavirus. In addition, for the time being, we have started implementing extraordinary measures to deny entry of foreign nationals who have any history of staying in Hubei Province within 14 days and those who possess a Chinese passport issued by Hubei Province, unless there is any specific need. I ask all of you to exert efforts to avoid trouble on the ground, by preventing those to whom those measures apply from boarding aircraft, through collaboration among relevant parties, including airlines. Furthermore, I ask the immigration authority to strictly implement these measures, including identifying individuals to whom those measures apply with a system capable of smoothly and easily making the relevant determination, and to exert efforts to implement it adequately by sufficiently paying attention to individuals’ circumstances." https://web.archive.org/web/20200518173226/http://japan.kantei.go.jp/98_abe/actions/202002/_00001.html

Cabinet Office Twitter -- Published informational leaflet on COVID-19 control; free to reprint, reproduce (https://web.archive.org/web/20200413192433/https://twitter.com/kantei_saigai/status/1224589187719946240)

Ministry of health, labour and welfare says "From the perspective of preventing the spread of infection, we ask event organizers to reconsider the necessity of holding the event in consideration of the spread of infection and the situation at the venue. Regarding the holding of events, etc., the government does not currently make a uniform request for self-restraint." https://web.archive.org/web/20200518113109/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/newpage_00002.html

Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare: "Encourage employees and other personnel to take days off if they have fever or other flu-like symptoms, and promote teleworking and staggered office hours. Recommends/encourages 1) paid workers leave for those infected or showing symptoms, and 2) a transition to working from home (online)" [https://web.archive.org/web/20200518123447/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10200000/000603611.pdf]

"Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare  https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/newpage_00032.html  https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10200000/000603610.pdf  Measures to be taken a) In communities where the number of patients continues to increase.; ·Switch to broader calls for refraining from going out, while reducing the scale of active epidemiology surveys and health observations on close contacts."

"Take general infection control measures thoroughly to prevent the infection from spreading in the facilities for the elderly if there is a suspected case of the novel coronavirus infection, while ensuring the smooth transition to hospitalized medical care for those with the high risk."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404090710/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10200000/000603610.pdf

Government instructs mask sellers to sell directly to the government "In light of such a situation and the request from Governor of Hokkaido Suzuki, we intend to deliver facial masks that the Government has made a lump-sum purchase of to the residents of the municipalities in Hokkaido, where the number of patients are increasing. We have decided to instruct manufacturers of facial masks to sell them to the Government, pursuant to the Act on Emergency Measures for Stabilizing Living Conditions of the Public. I ask the relevant Ministries and Agencies, including the Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare, to start working on specific measures so as to deliver facial masks to the residents as early as possible." http://web.archive.org/web/20200901201539/https://japan.kantei.go.jp/98_abe/actions/202003/_00001.html

"Almost all prefectures across the nation began shutting schools Monday in a bid to prevent further spread of the new coronavirus that causes COVID-19, four days after Prime Minister Shinzo Abe issued a shock request for a total school closure until early April."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200514234259/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2020/03/02/national/japan-prefectures-shut-schools-covid-19/    The national govt guidelines are not strict though, and Prefectures have the option not to close schools:  https://web.archive.org/web/20200514234005/https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2020/02/b341be1ebf20-breaking-news-children-should-stay-home-while-schools-closed-over-virus-japan-govt.html

Ministry of health, labour and welfare  https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/newpage_00032.html  Anyone who has boarded an airplane or ships arriving from China or Republic of Korea at or after 0:00 on March 9 (JST)…….  and not be isolated or stopped is required to stay 14days at a location designated by the quarantine station chief and not to use public transportation in Japan.

The Government of Japan has announced broad  debt and contract relief to households, small and medium enterprises and large corporations. On the 16th of March, the government announced credit measures for corporations. Further debt support and relief measures were announced on the 27th of April and 22nd of May. These measures inlcude funding against loans and intrest free unsecured loans.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Ministry of Justice  https://web.archive.org/web/20200406045943/http://www.moj.go.jp/content/001316999.pdf  the Ministry of Justice considers foreign nationals who fall under any of the following to be foreign nationals who fall under Article 5, paragraph (1), item (xiv) of the Immigration Control and Refugee Recognition Act (hereinafter referred to as the “Immigration Control Act”) and unless the foreign national has special exceptional circumstances, the foreign national will be subject to denial of landing

A month-long State of Emergency is issued by Prime Minister Abe in 7 prefectures of Japan.  [https://web.archive.org/web/20200504145003/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/apr/07/japan-shinzo-abe-declares-state-of-emergency-over-coronavirus]  However, the State of Emergency will only "give prefectural governors the authority to call on people to stay at home".   "Municipal leaders can merely request that residents under their jurisdiction stay indoors as much as possible."  [https://web.archive.org/web/20200518181408/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2020/03/01/national/japan-coronavirus-outbreak/]

Only within selected prefectures:  "The Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare will notify and ensure the  following measures, from the viewpoint of thoroughly preventing nosocomial  infection in medical institutions and facilities for the elderly, under  cooperation with local governments.  - Take every possible precaution to prevent workers from being a source of  infection by thoroughly avoiding the place where "3Cs" overlap at the same  time, by making sure for workers to wear masks, wash and disinfect hands,  disinfect regularly shared facilities, maintain a certain distance each other  when eating and drinking, keep their daily health tracks and stay home if  their physical condition is not perfect.  - Temporarily cease reception of visits except for emergency in order to  prevent infection from visiting persons.  - Consider measures such as suspending or restricting temporary use of  facilities such as day-care, limiting outings and overnight stays of  inpatients and users, in areas where infection is prevalent.  - Isolate a suspected case immediately and implement infection  countermeasures under the guidance of public health centers, in case of  suspecting a new case of COVID-19 infection from hospitalized patients or  users"    http://web.archive.org/web/20210110131546/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000620733.pdf
State of Emergency order extended to all 47 prefectures.  [https://web.archive.org/web/20200518181631/https://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20200416/p2g/00m/0na/085000c]

Quotation: "Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has promised to give a one-off sum of ¥100,000 ($930) to every citizen of Japan in a stepped-up response to the coronavirus outbreak as he declared a state of emergency across the whole country."  Link: https://www.ft.com/content/4053e198-437e-4ae5-aab5-fa0ab05f3fa3

Restrictions expanded to all Japanese prefectures:    "The MHLW will also notify and ensure the following measures to thoroughly  prevent nosocomial infection in medical institutions and facilities for the  elderly.  - Take every possible precautious measure to prevent workers from being a  source of infection including by thoroughly avoiding the 3-Cs.  5  - Temporarily stop receiving visitors except for emergency cases in order to  prevent infection.  - Consider measures such as suspending or restricting temporary use of  such facilities in areas where infection is prevalent.  - Isolate a suspected patient immediately and implement counter-infection  measures under the guidance of public health centers."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210110131747/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000624195.pdf

The state of emergency has been lifted in 39 prefectures. The lifting of the state of emergency in the remaining 8 prefectures will be reviewed on 21 May.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200514234850/https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2020/05/8128172584ce-japan-may-lift-coronavirus-emergency-in-kyoto-38-other-prefectures.html

As the state of emergency is lifted in 39 prefectures, there is no more nation-wide recommendation of canceling public events. However, individual provincial governments might still take the initiative of canceling such events.      https://web.archive.org/web/20200514234850/https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2020/05/8128172584ce-japan-may-lift-coronavirus-emergency-in-kyoto-38-other-prefectures.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20200514235808/https://corona.go.jp/en/news/pdf/000628609.pdf

State of Emergency lifted in some prefectures, but still in place in those more at risk of disease spread.  "Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe on Thursday lifted a state of emergency for 39 of the country's 47 prefectures ahead of its planned expiration at the end of the month, paving the way for businesses to gradually resume operations as the spread of the new coronavirus has been kept in check.    Urban regions such as Tokyo and Osaka, however, will remain under the state of emergency and people will be asked to stay at home to ensure newly reported cases continue to fall and the burden on hospitals eases."  [https://web.archive.org/web/20200514234850/https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2020/05/8128172584ce-japan-may-lift-coronavirus-emergency-in-kyoto-38-other-prefectures.html]

Emergency status is lifted. There are guidelines for voluntary business closures, but generally, the govt wants economic activity to restart so they did not issue any recommendation to close.    https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2020/05/25/national/japan-lifts-state-of-emergency-coronavirus/
Japan lifts state of emergency in all 39 prefectures:    https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2020/05/25/national/japan-lifts-state-of-emergency-coronavirus/

Although emergency state was lifted, interprefectural travel was not recommended until 19 June:    https://web.archive.org/web/20200712221911oe_/https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2020/06/bd98aeff84d2-freedom-of-travel-restored-across-japan-as-virus-fears-ease.html

Some schools are closed because of outbreaks or local govt recommendations, but most schools are open with some measures in place  In most prefectures of Japan, schools have reopened by June 1. However, the situation continues to be monitored on the local level, and municipalities can choose to keep some schools closed or to close them again. Most universities are still conducting research and teaching in an online format to the greatest possible extent. (1.) For example, on June 13,  a local cluster was found in a Kitakyushu school, leading to an announcement that the school will be closed again. (2.)     (1.) https://archive.vn/oUa0v   (2.) https://archive.vn/D8EL1    https://www.mext.go.jp/content/20200603-mxt_kouhou01-000004520_4.pdf (For reviewers and updaters: Web archive services are unavailable in China, please archive this link when you see this)  Education Ministry  98% of the schools in total of all levels have reopened as of 1 June.    Note from 21 Aug: "Many schools across the nation reopened Monday after summer vacations were shortened to allow students to catch up on classes missed when schools closed due to the novel coronavirus pandemic."      https://web.archive.org/web/20200821005509/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2020/08/17/national/japan-schools-restart-coronavirus/

***Recoded from 1A to 2A based on new information, see below:     Have to revise up because I found new information.    Eligible: workers from small and medium-sized businesses which were closed between April 1, Reiwa 2 (2020) and February 28, Reiwa 3 (2021) because of the novel coronavirus and measures to prevent its spread, so who were unable to receive payment of wages (leave allowance) during this period.    Amount paid:  Of pre-holiday wages 80% (Maximum daily amount 11,000yen)  In addition, as maternal health management measures related to the novel coronavirus infection, a paid leave system is established. This applies to pregnant female workers who are required to take leave under the guidance of a doctor or midwife has been established. The transport ministry is also now arranging for Airport Transport Service Co. to run shuttle buses from Narita and Haneda airports to some 12 hotels within Tokyo to relieve travelers of expensive taxi fares, ministry official Keita Yamamoto said. April: On April 12, Japan began administering vaccines to senior citizens age 65 and older. There are roughly 36 million people making up Japan's elderly population.    May: NHK reports that local regulators will decide by May 20 whether to approve the Moderna and AstraZeneca vaccines. Japan is set to receive 100 million doses of the Pfizer vaccine between May and June.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517231133/https://www.timeout.com/tokyo/news/heres-the-tentative-timeline-of-japans-covid-19-vaccination-programme-012021    C. Japan declared a state of emergency from April 25 - May 11 with restrictions in Tokyo, Osaka, Kyoto, and Hyogo prefectures. Establishments that sell alcohol or offer karaoke will be asked to close or face fines. In Okinawa Prefecture beginning June 7 until June 20, due to the ongoing state of emergency, all events regardless of size or location are to be postponed or cancelled: exemptions include events with no live audience, exams, or business recruitment activities. Until now, events with less than 1,000 people are to be held at facilities permitting 50% capacity, but after June 7, events are to be postponed or cancelled.  For events with 1,000 people or less, the notification period between June 3-6 will come into effect June 7. Tickets that have been sold by the end of the notification period do not need to be cancelled if the maximum number of people is 1,000 or less. After the notification period, new tickets are not permitted to be sold.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607070236/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0603taisyohoshin.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210701184519/https://www.okinawatimes.co.jp/articles/-/764514  https://web.archive.org/web/20210701194515/https://ryukyushimpo.jp/news/entry-1333234.html

Overall priority for vaccination remains the same: with Priority Group 1 being high risk healthcare workers, Priority Group 2 being elderly 65+, Priority Group 3 being those under 65 with underlying conditions, and Priority 4 being staff in contact with the elderly and vulnerable populations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210716223102/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000756894.pdf

On June 21, the temporary closure of prefectural schools in Okinawa has lifted. Schools are asked to resume complying with all infection prevention protocols and depending on infection rates in the locale, to stagger school attendance by groups.  In other prefectures, schools at all levels continue to remain open with cautionary measures including increased ventilations in classrooms, the wearing of masks in close quarters, and the establishment of a health management system for school doctors and pharmacists. There is currently no region-wide suspension on educational institutions and any temporary closure of schools are assessed on an individual basis.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621193410/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0617taisyohoshin.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210629231552/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0621english.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621010823/https://www.mext.go.jp/a_menu/coronavirus/mext_00020.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210629202136/https://www.kobe-np.co.jp/news/sougou/202106/0014458000.shtml  https://web.archive.org/web/20210629202245/https://www.tokyo-np.co.jp/article/113016

As of June 21, the government begins inoculating occupational sites for universities and companies that have submitted applications for workplace vaccination. Over 13.73 million employees of 3,400 workplaces are scheduled for vaccination at 260 venues. 17 universities begin vaccinations for all students, faculty, staff, and associated frontline employees across 11 prefectures: Hokkaido Medical University; Tokushima University; Tokyo International University; Tokyo University, Keio University, Nihon University, Japan Physical Education University; Shonan Institute of Technology; Matsumoto Dental University; Osaka University, Osaka University of Economics and Law, Kansai University, Kinki University, Yamato University; Kobe City College of Nursing; Hiroshima University; Tokushima University; Nagasaki International University.  This is in addition to high risk medical workers and those age 65+ that can already access vaccination. As of July 11, 76% of the eligible elderly population have received their first dose, 46% have received their second dose.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210711231359/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00218.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210711231750/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/flow/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210711235125/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210621/k10013095001000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210711233304/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/workplace.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210711230618/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210711/k10013133021000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210711232949/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210621/k10013095451000.html

In hopes of accelerating vaccination efforts, on June 21, occupational sites and universities begin inoculations for workplaces that have submitted an application. This group includes roughly 13.73 million people and were not included in the original list for priority vaccinations. By targeting all workplaces from large to small companies, the government looks to achieve prevent further spread of infection and disruption of economic activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210711231359/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00218.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210711235125/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210621/k10013095001000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210711233546/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210708/k10013126881000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210716220739/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210716/k10013143611000.html

All vaccinations are fully covered by the government. However, workplace venues may be at the discretion of companies with the government subsidizing a portion of the venue cost if multiple companies apply together.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210711231359/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00218.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210711235125/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210621/k10013095001000.html

Announced June 8, Okinawa has extended their state of emergency until August 22, however events with a maximum of 1,000 people may proceed to be held.  On June 8, Govenor of Tokyo has also announced that the metropolitan area of Tokyo will begin its 4th state of emergency from July 12 to August 22.    In the rest of Japan, if the gathering does not require loud cheering, the event may proceed at 100% facility capacity for a maximum of 5,000 people or less. For gatherings with loud cheering, the event may proceed at 50% facility capacity for a maximum of 5,000 people or less. All events must end at 9pm in prefectures with priority measures.    Local governments continue to encourage residents to stay home and to avoid going to crowded places or engaging in high risk activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210710022009/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210710024233/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/014/242/2021078/a.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210710024303/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0708taisyo.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210710030024/https://www.pref.osaka.lg.jp/kikaku/kinkyuzitai-20210425/manenboushi-0712.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210710030149/https://www.pref.saitama.lg.jp/a0401/covid19/saitamaken_zyuutensochi0708.html

According to reports and interviews from prefectures of Tokyo and Saitama, due to the high number of infections, close contact tracing has been overwhelmed and efforts have shifted to targeted/priority settings such as schools or elderly facilities.  For other prefectures, small-cluster contact tracing continues to be manually and comprehensively conducted, in addition to the utilization of the COVID-19 Contact-Confirming Application (COCOA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210814022625/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210814/k10013201711000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814030232/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.html

Yokohama City has announced it will temporarily close elementary and junior high schools to delay reopening after summer vacation past August 29. A further announcement will be made beginning next week with details on the closure. In Kanagawa Prefecture, Sagamihara City and Kawasaki City have also decided to temporarily close municipal elementary and junior high schools throughout the month of August.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210822072727/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210821/k10013215561000.html

On August 25, Pregnant women have been added to the list eligible for priority vaccination, in addition to the previous groups outlined: with Priority Group 1 being high risk healthcare workers, Priority Group 2 being elderly 65+, Priority Group 3 being those under 65 with underlying conditions, and Priority 4 being staff in contact with the elderly and vulnerable populations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210827205504/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210825/k10013221291000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210827210022/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00218.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210809210816/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000756894.pdf

On August 25, Pregnant women are now eligible for vaccinations at both local clinics and the Tokyo mass vaccination clinic. Occupational sites and universities continue to be inoculated at workplaces that have submitted an application. As of August 25, 12 million doses have been administered for occupational inoculation that were not included in the original list for priority vaccinations. On September 4, mass vaccination centres in Tokyo and Osaka will begin prioritized inoculations for younger generations (age 18-39). In the month of September, the vaccination sites have set a quota to vaccinate 30,000 young people and priority slots for the younger generation can be booked online beginning 6pm on September 3. The government has also announced the mass vaccination centres will extend operations until at least the end of November in order to accelerate vaccination efforts.    Those who are eligible to be inoculated at the mass vaccination sites include 65+, pregnant women, and ages 18-39.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210905234805/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210902/k10013239891000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210905234311/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210905235910/https://www.mod.go.jp/j/approach/defense/saigai/2020/covid/covid_intokyo.html

On September 4, Tokyo and Osaka begin prioritized inoculations for younger generations (age 18-39); meanwhile many regions in Japan have already begun inoculating individuals 12+. Pregnant women continue to be prioritized for vaccinations at both local clinics and the mass vaccination clinics. Occupational sites and universities continue to be inoculated at workplaces that have submitted an application.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210905234805/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210902/k10013239891000.html (prioritized youth)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924215514/https://www.mod.go.jp/j/approach/defense/saigai/2020/covid/covid_intokyo.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924215600/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00218.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924215609/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210905233353/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210902/k10013239651000.html (pregnant women)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210716220739/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210716/k10013143611000.html (occupational)
