However, workplace venues may be at the discretion of companies with the government subsidizing a portion of the venue cost if multiple companies apply together.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210924215600/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00218.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210711235125/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210621/k10013095001000.html

On September 11, priority inoculation for the younger generation (ages 18-39) begin in Osaka mass vaccination site.  Within Taito ward of Tokyo, efforts are being made to mass vaccinate those who are homeless to prevent spread of infection in vulnerable populations.  In Katsushika ward of Tokyo, priority vaccination of elementary school children and junior high school students begin in mass vaccination venues. Children who have a resident card from elementary 6th grade to junior high 3rd grade are eligible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210917235431/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210911/k10013254511000.html (Osaka youth vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210917235506/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210913/k10013257031000.html (Taito homeless vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210917235620/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210911/k10013255201000.html (Katsushika priority children vaccination)

Schools in many regions have resumed in-person learning, however, school attendance is largely part-time through staggering grades or shortening classes to reduce the number of students on-site at any one time. All other days of the week for students are spent in online lessons.  For many wards and prefectures, online schooling is also a voluntary option available to students and parents during the state of emergency.  From September 20 to 26, all public schools in Tokyo Metropolitan Area announced there will be a temporary suspension of in-person learning during Silver Week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910022721/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210909/k10013252101000.html (Silver Week suspension in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210918025123/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210913/k10013256991000.html (summary of school attendance in Tokyo's 23 wards)

On September 13, the federal government announces nationwide request for local governments and local university vaccination clinics to offer priority vaccination to junior high and high school students who will be sitting entrance exams.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210922150111/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210914/k10013258481000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210922150212/https://www.mext.go.jp/content/20210914-mxt_kouhou01-000004520_1.pdf

On September 13, the federal government announces nationwide request for local governments and local university vaccination clinics to offer priority vaccination generally to junior high and high school students who will be sitting entrance exams.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210922150111/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210914/k10013258481000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210922150212/https://www.mext.go.jp/content/20210914-mxt_kouhou01-000004520_1.pdf

All vaccinations continue to be fully covered by the government. However, workplace venues may be at the discretion of companies with the government subsidizing a portion of the venue cost if multiple companies apply together.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210924215600/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00218.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210711235125/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210621/k10013095001000.html

During "Silver Week", all public schools in Tokyo Metropolitan Area from September 20 to 26 will be temporarily closed to in-person learning. Students are expected to return on Sep 27.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910022721/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210909/k10013252101000.html (Silver Week suspension in Tokyo)

The a week suspension of in-person learning for students in the Metropolitan Tokyo area has ended and all classes have resumed inline with other prefectures across Japan.  The government of Japan has decided all emergency and priority measures will be lighted for all prefectures on October 1. Included, all schools across Japan currently stagger attendance by grades or classes will resume full capacity in-person learning on October 1. Continued focus on sanization, contact tracing within schools, and restrictions on club activities or school excursions will remain. Individual schools also have the jurisdiction to temporarily close due to infection outbreaks on a case-by-case basis.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910022721/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210909/k10013252101000.html (Silver Week)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003032546/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210928/k10013280271000.html (Resumption of school)

On October 1, Japan lifts emergency and priority measures for all prefectures and will undergo a precautionary period for one month. From Oct 1 to Oct 24, Tokyo will undergo a period with various lighter restrictions. For Okinawa, the precautionary period is between Oct 1 to Oct 31.    All businesses including bars and nightclubs are able to reopen provided businesses serving alcohol receives a certificate of inspection for infection control by the Ministry of Health, however karaoke equipment is requested not to be used. During the precautionary period, all businesses are requested to operate at shortened business hours between 5:00AM to 9:00PM with alcohol permitted to being served 11:00AM to 8:00PM (in Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, and Okinawa). In Tochigi, alcohol may be served until 7:30PM; and in Okinawa, acohol may be served until 7:00PM.  Businesses are asked to reduce the number of workers in the office by 70% through utilizing remote methods of work and to request employees finish work by 8:00PM.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190427/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193347/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210929/k10013281591000.html (restrictions in Kanto region)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193702/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210928/k10013281561000.html (restrictioins in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190640/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/638/20211001.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190745/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0928taisyohoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa)

On October 1, Japan lifts emergency and priority measures for all prefectures and will undergo a precautionary period for one month. From Oct 1 to Oct 24, Tokyo will undergo a period with various lighter restrictions. For Okinawa, the precautionary period is between Oct 1 to Oct 31.    During the precautionary period, all events are asked to be completed by 9:00PM. For events involving loud events, capacity is limited to 50% of the venue capacity and not exceed an upper limit of 10,000 people. For events with no loud voices, 100% of the venue capacity may be used but not exceed an upper limit of 5,000 people. In Okinawa, loud events are limited to 50% venue capacity and must not exceed 5,000 people.  Businesses are asked to reduce the number of workers in the office by 70% through utilizing remote methods of work and to request employees finish work by 8:00PM. Drinking gatherings at bars are asked to to be limited to 4 people per group.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190427/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193347/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210929/k10013281591000.html (restrictions in Kanto region)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193702/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210928/k10013281561000.html (restrictioins in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190640/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/638/20211001.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190745/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0928taisyohoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa)

On October 4, walk-in (no reservation) vaccinations begin for residents 16 years old and up at mass vaccination venues in Osaka Prefecture. Beginning November 24 2021, the government begins allowing visitations at long-term care homes restricted to visitors who have been fully vaccinated with two doses of the COVID-19 vaccination or have had a negative PCR test prior to the visitation.    Last report on provisional measures in nursing homes was published as of December 27, 2021.  The following preventative measures for the elderly also continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Supply infection prevention items such as masks, other PPE, and disinfectants,  - Comprehensive information and training material for Long Term Care staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054033/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211110/k10013341201000.html (visitations for fully vaccinated visitors)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130023257/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211125/k10013360411000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123222226/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123222227/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html

With regard to direct taxes, the modalities of the advance tax payments and payment deadlines will be adapted for corporations and self-employed persons. More specifically, legal persons and natural persons carrying out an activity generating trade and business income, agriculture and forestry income, or income from independent professional services, who are experiencing liquidity problems due to the Covid-19 pandemic, can apply for a cancellation of the two first quarterly advance tax payments of the year 2020 (due in March and June 2020). Covered by this measure are (corporate) income and municipal business taxes.    In addition, these same persons may request, for taxes due after 29 February 2020, a payment extension of four months. On this deferral, no interest on late payment will be due and it covers (corporate) income, municipal business, and net wealth taxes.  https://mfin.gouvernement.lu/en/actualites.gouvernement%2Ben%2Bactualites%2Btoutes_actualites%2Bcommuniques%2B2020%2B03-mars%2B17-mesures-fiscales-covid19.html

On April 8th, the government published a document, titled “Covid-19: wearing a mask as an additional barrier gesture”, which stated:   “The virus that causes COVID-19 is capable of being transmitted even in the absence of symptoms. It is therefore recommended to cover the mouth and the nose, by a mask or even by another fabric, especially in public places where interpersonal distancing is difficult to maintain.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200912162042/https://sante.public.lu/fr/actualites/2020/04/covid-19-port-du-masque-geste-barriere-additionnel/masque-brochure.pdf & http://web.archive.org/web/20200818062929/https://sante.public.lu/fr/actualites/2020/04/covid-19-port-du-masque-geste-barriere-additionnel/index.html

The country is now entering the exit phase of lockdown and closures, limited movement is still advised while the country gradually reopens     https://archive.fo/wip/MwplB

Luxembourg enforced the use of masks. Prime Minister Xavier Bettel said: “people would be required to use a mask or other covering such as a scarf over their mouths if they were not able to keep 2 metres away from each other.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200912161628if_/https://uk.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-luxembourg-idUKKBN2221W3
Recommended protections in place for the cautious lifting of confinement measures. No specific measures in place for elderly persons.  source: https://archive.fo/MwplB

While doing the C1 review, I looked at the ministry of education’s archive of press announcements. There is an announcement that secondary education restarted on 4th May.    https://archive.vn/ocgHa    Per previous coding, Schools resumed their classes on Monday 11 May, one week after the first and final students. Pupils returning to school will be separated, circulation will be controlled, and masks are obligatory if two metre distance cannot be kept.    https://archive.vn/6z5nL    Subsequent coding comment indicates that primary schools were still closed until including 24th May, so 2G is valid for this period (at least one level fully closed). Unfortunately, the source had not been archived and now 404s.   Source from previous coding: https://covid19.public.lu/fr/communications-officielles.gouvernement+fr+actualites+toutes_actualites+articles+2020+05-mai+15-meisch-reprise-enseignement.html    Found a different source on the ministry’s website that explains the tiered school re-opening:  •	From 4th May: final classes in secondary education  •	From 11th May: all other classes in secondary education, but not elementary schools  •	From 25th May: Elementary schools    https://archive.vn/i7rrk
Full reopening of businesses but recommend work from home if possible

https://gouvernement.lu/en/actualites/toutes_actualites/communiques/2020/04-avril/28-strategie-deconfinement-sante-recherche.html:  "Due to the size of Luxembourg and its limited number of residents, we have a great opportunity: we can test the entire population for the novel coronavirus within a short period of time. This makes us the first country in the world to have a complete overview of the number of infected citizens," said Minister of Higher Education and Research, Claude Meisch.

Previous coding: 0  New coding: 1G    Health measures include wearing of masks, social distancing, frequent hand washing. Also distribution of masks, disinfectants, transparent barriers, and other hygiene measures by the government / ministry of education.  https://archive.vn/iLwYD  http://web.archive.org/web/20201006122016/https://men.public.lu/fr/actualites/communiques-conference-presse/2020/09/25-dispositif-cas-isole.html    Schools are closed for the summer holidays which started “on Thursday 16 July 2020 and end on Monday 14 September 2020”. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200823230049/https://guichet.public.lu/en/outils/calendrier-scolaire.html Schools are due to be reopening in September. On August 14th, Minister of Education, Claude Meisch, “stated that the virus could be controlled within schools using appropriate measures, and emphasised the that protecting the most vulnerable should be the priority moving forward. As such, the ministry's current goal is to allow educational activities to take place with minimal restrictions.”   Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200823231016/https://today.rtl.lu/news/luxembourg/a/1564785.html    On September 9th, The Ministry of National Education, Children and Youth shared forecasts that “107,153 students will return to school on September 15, 2020, all levels of education combined, public and private included. This figure rises to 152,153 learners when adult education is included. In public primary and secondary education, 10,891 teachers will also return to school next week.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200912132748/https://menej.gouvernement.lu/fr/support/recherche.gouvernement%2Bfr%2Bactualites%2Btoutes_actualites%2Bcommuniques%2B2020%2B09-septembre%2B09-chiffres-rentree.html    Schools are open for fall 2020 with strict health measures.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201105232540/https://men.public.lu/fr/support/coronavirus/faq-en.html    On the 25th of September, The Minister of Health, and the Minister of National Education, Children and Youth, announced that the government has decided to expand the extraordinary family leave related to COVID-19, to allow parents to stay with their children outside of school hours. They also provided details on the different scenarios of the health system to fight against the spread of COVID-19 in schools. http://web.archive.org/web/20201006122016/https://men.public.lu/fr/actualites/communiques-conference-presse/2020/09/25-dispositif-cas-isole.html    Health measures for the 2020-21 school year:    To be able to contain the risk of contamination in school, the necessary health measures are being maintained:  In the classroom:  •	limited movement of pupils,  •	a fixed place for each pupil,  •	aeration and ventilation at regular intervals, with due regard for the safety of pupils (see point 3.3 of the instructions for elementary education staff and point 3.2 of the instructions for secondary education staff)  •	regular cleaning of surfaces,  •	increased hand hygiene (hand washing before start of lessons, after each break, after going to the toilet, before and after each meal)  •	social hygiene: coughing and sneezing into the crook of the elbow, avoiding physical touching (no handshaking, etc).  Within the school:  •	wearing a mask (see question below),  •	staggered breaks,  •	regular cleaning of toilets, etc,  •	fewer contacts outside the classroom,  •	organisation of movements in the school building.    Secondary schools may adopt additional measures, such as making the wearing of a mask compulsory in the classroom, or organising higher classes on an alternating basis (e.g. alternate weeks physically present in the classroom).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201018164843/https://men.public.lu/fr/support/coronavirus/faq-en.html

With third phase, some cultural, religious and sport events will be allowed to happen again https://5minutes.rtl.lu/actu/luxembourg/a/1523856.html  ** Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200602140303/https://5minutes.rtl.lu/actu/luxembourg/a/1523856.html

Wearing a mask is compulsory for staff and travelers.  The front door of the bus remains closed. Travelers are asked to get on and off through the rear doors.  The 1 st row of passenger seats must remain unoccupied to the extent possible.  The driver does not sell tickets (RegioZone).  Travelers are requested to keep their distance    source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200616041859/https://www.mobiliteit.lu/fr/coronavirus-fr/

You can organise or participate in public events with more than twenty people indoors or outdoors (cultural or sports events, congresses, etc.), provided that the following two rules apply:    People are seated in seats that have been designated for them,  Either they are two meters apart or they are wearing the mask.  Wearing a mask is compulsory for the people supervising the event and those circulating on the premises.    Compliance with these measures is also essential to enable restaurants, cafes, bars, consumer lounges and company canteens to function. If the space between the tables side by side does not allow a distance of at least 1.5 metres, they must be separated by a device such as a screen or panel.    No upper limit to how many people can take part in an event has been given, thus coded as '0'. But can be assumed that gathering size is limited to the capacity that a venue has to enact the above requirements.     http://archive.vn/2RUFn  http://archive.vn/4jnOQ

There is no indication that internal movement is restricted. The requirements to wear a facemask persist, especially on public transit and in public spaces where social distancing cannot be achieved.   http://archive.vn/4jnOQ

On July 16th, the government updates its coronavirus policy: "masks are mandatory for gatherings of more than 20 people in public settings if physical distance of 2m cannot be guaranteed while remaining seated. The rule does not apply to markets."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200727034758/https://lu.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

On july 19th, the government of Luxembourg adopted new measures to combat the spread of the virus which includes, "no more than 10 people can gather in a private setting." https://web.archive.org/web/20200727034758/https://lu.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    *Recoded from a 3 to 4 since 10 people is now included in the definition for a 4.

The government response to “When to wear a mask”: “Cultural, sports and leisure activities cannot accommodate the public if the conditions of wearing a mask and/or distancing are not respected” was changed to “Religious, cultural and sports actors are also exempted from wearing masks while carrying out their activities”. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200720154130/https://msan.gouvernement.lu/en/dossiers/2020/corona-virus.html (July 20th) & http://web.archive.org/web/20200721154136/https://msan.gouvernement.lu/en/dossiers/2020/corona-virus.html (July 21st)

“It is compulsory to cover your nose and mouth with a mask, scarf or bandana…for activities that welcome the public (shops, counters, recycling center, fairs and exhibitions, markets). Cultural, sporting and leisure activities cannot welcome the public if the conditions for wearing a mask and / or distancing are not respected.” https://web.archive.org/web/20200824155352/https://coronavirus.gouvernement.lu/fr/citoyens.html

“Effective August 12, 2020, third-country nationals aged 11 or over seeking to enter Luxembourg by air, whose travel does not originate from an EU member country or one of the countries exempted by the European Union (Australia, Canada, China (subject to reciprocity at European Union level), Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Korea from the South, Thailand, Tunisia and Uruguay), must provide proof of a negative COVID-19 test at the time of boarding. This test must have been administered less than 48 hours before the flight.” Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200823232004/https://lu.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

“Measures concerning the entry into Luxembourg of third-county nationals” were updated on the 21st August. “Due to the Covid-19 pandemic, the ban on the entry of third-country nationals into the territory of Luxembourg is valid until 15 September 2020.” However, there are exceptions, including for diplomats, third-country nationals travelling for the purpose of study, and healthcare professionals, health researchers, and elderly care professionals. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200902223324/https://guichet.public.lu/en/actualites/2020/aout/11-nouvelles-mesures-entree-ressortissant-tiers.html

As of Nov.5, not able to find exact historical policy for the period of Oct. 20 to Oct. 29. But based on the RTL news (source below): private gathering limit was reduced from 10 to 4 people from Oct. 30, which implies 10 people was the limit before Oct. 30, and that aligns with the policy recorded before Oct. 20. So record this indicator as 2 "require cancelling", following coding interpretation guideline (Nov.4 version) "When private gatherings of only 10 or less are permitted (e.g. C4=4), this restriction would prevent public events from taking place, so they are recorded as required to cancel."  Sources:  http://web.archive.org/web/20201106013947/https://today.rtl.lu/news/luxembourg/a/1604513.html

Curfew in effect from Oct. 30: "between 11 P.M. and 6 A.M., movements of people in the public space are prohibited". According to coding interpretation guideline, record curfew as a level 2.  Sources:   http://web.archive.org/web/20201106013231/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/curfew.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20201106013947/https://today.rtl.lu/news/luxembourg/a/1604513.html

New measures effective from Oct. 30:   "Wearing a mask is compulsory for gatherings of more than 4 people whether they take place indoors or outdoors."   "It is compulsory to cover your nose and mouth with a mask, scarf or bandana on public transport and for activities that are open to the public (shops, counters, recycling centres, fairs and exhibitions, markets)."  "Cultural, sports and leisure activities cannot accommodate the public if the conditions of wearing a mask and/or distancing are not respected."  More details on the official government website and RTL news below:  http://web.archive.org/web/20201106052524/https://covid19.public.lu/en/health-protection/protective-measures.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20201106013947/https://today.rtl.lu/news/luxembourg/a/1604513.html

The first people to be vaccinated are health professionals and staff in hospitals, as well as ambulance drivers, staff in residential care facilities for the elderly and in care and support networks, and people living in these facilities. On Thursday 28 and 29 December, around 800 people from the hospital sector will be vaccinated, and 200 people per hospital establishment for acute treatments respectively. On Wednesday 30 December, staff from senior citizens' homes will be vaccinated - with an additional 400 vaccinations planned. In addition, paramedics transporting COVID-19 patients were offered vaccination during these three days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103233531/https://gouvernement.lu/en/actualites/toutes_actualites/communiques/2020/12-decembre/28-vaccin-covid.html

Vaccination strategy in luxembourg   1.protect the most vulnerable residents (based on their age or health status) from the risk of complications from the disease and from the risk of death, and  2.protect the capacity of our health care system.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210810054120/https://covid19.public.lu/en/vaccination.html    The Higher Council for Infectious Diseases issues an opinion on the prioritization of vaccination against COVID-19 in Luxembourg; this prioritization, based on the data and information available, is broken down into successive phases, depending on vaccine availability:  ** Phase 1 (in progress since December 28, 2020): healthcare professionals and staff of health establishments and accommodation structures, as well that residents of these establishments and structures. (The first phase of the vaccination deployment is underway; it concerns professionals  of health and care as well as residents of accommodation structures for the elderly and for disabled people, and the staff of these structures.)    ** Phase 2: highly vulnerable people (In view of the data collected on the vulnerability criteria since the start of the pandemic, the second phase of the deployment of the vaccination strategy should concern the people highly vulnerable because of their age or because of a pre-existing medical condition. These are the people aged 75 and over (not staying in nursing homes or integrated centers for elderly), starting with the oldest, as well as people with Down's syndrome, people who have had an organ or hematopoietic stem cell transplant from patients with cancer or malignant hemopathy under treatment, and patients with a deficiency congenital immune system.)    ** Phase 3: significantly vulnerable people (The third phase will concern people whose risk of severe or fatal development is, depending on the  majority of sources, significantly higher than in the general population. These are the people aged 70 to 74, as well as patients with acquired immune deficiency, patients with severe cardiovascular disease, patients with respiratory disease severe chronic disease, people with end-stage kidney disease or cirrhosis of the Child-Pugh stage B or C, obese people with a BMI> 40 kg / m2, and people with a major neurocognitive deficit)    **Phase 4: moderately vulnerable people (The fourth phase concerns people who are moderately vulnerable, either because of their age  between 65 and 69 years old, or due to a pre-existing state of health: diabetes with complications cardiovascular, arterial hypertension with complications (sequelae of stroke, heart disease) or neuromuscular disease with clinical repercussions.)    **Phase 5: people who may be exposed to an increased risk ( concerns people whose vulnerability, in the absence of another criterion of  risk, is not formally demonstrated. These are people aged 55 to 64 as well as people with uncomplicated diabetes or hypertension, or obesity with BMI between 30 and 40 kg / m2.)    Phase 6: specific categories and the general population (attention to the special situation of people living in a precarious situation or to people living in closed communities (prison environment by example), particularly at risk of transmission within their community; in addition,  certain categories of people are particularly exposed to the risk of acquiring infection in the course of their occupation, such as slaughterhouse staff. And the vaccination strategy should involve the general population under 55 years.)    https://web.archive.org/web/20210727055657/https://covid19.public.lu/dam-assets/covid-19/documents/strategie-vaccinale/CSMI-avis-priorisation-vaccin-COVID-19-phases-2-et-suivantes-20210127.pdf    **The first people to be vaccinated are health professionals and staff in hospitals, as well as ambulance drivers, paramedics, staff in residential care facilities for the elderly and in care and support networks, and people living in these facilities. https://web.archive.org/web/20210103233531/https://gouvernement.lu/en/actualites/toutes_actualites/communiques/2020/12-decembre/28-vaccin-covid.html**

Phase 1:  The first people to be vaccinated are health professionals and staff in hospitals, as well as ambulance drivers, staff in residential care facilities for the elderly and in care and support networks, and people living in these facilities. On Thursday 28 and 29 December, around 800 people from the hospital sector will be vaccinated, and 200 people per hospital establishment for acute treatments respectively. On Wednesday 30 December, staff from senior citizens' homes will be vaccinated - with an additional 400 vaccinations planned. In addition, paramedics transporting COVID-19 patients were offered vaccination during these three days. https://web.archive.org/web/20210103233531/https://gouvernement.lu/en/actualites/toutes_actualites/communiques/2020/12-decembre/28-vaccin-covid.html    Between 6 and 14 January, it is planned to vaccinate the residents of 11 nursing homes, according to a list drawn up by the Ministry for the Family, Integration and the Greater Region, in close collaboration with COPAS. This will be followed by other nursing homes and integrated centres for the elderly (Centres intégrés pour personnes âgées - CIPA) in the country. In the end, 6,200 residents will be able to be vaccinated against SARS-CoV-2.  It should also be noted that all staff in nursing homes (6,332 health professionals and 8,927 other professionals) will also be vaccinated over the next few weeks in the vaccination centres. The first vaccinations have already been carried out on 30 December.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210810063747/https://msan.gouvernement.lu/en/actualites.gouvernement%2Ben%2Bactualites%2Btoutes_actualites%2Bcommuniques%2B2021%2B01-janvier%2B06-vaccinations-maisons-soins.html    **Phase 2: January 26th 2021  Today the Government Council decided on the next phase of the vaccination campaign on the basis of the opinion of the National Ethics Commission (Commission nationale d'éthique, C.N.E.) of 21 January. intervenu en date du 21 janvier. The decision is in line with the dual objective underlying the vaccination strategy, namely the protection of the most vulnerable people according to their age or state of health and the protection of our health system.  The Government has therefore decided that, in the second phase, people aged 75 and over, both healthy and vulnerable, will be vaccinated, starting with the oldest. At the same time, highly vulnerable residents, with no age limit, will also be eligible to get vaccinated.    The second phase of the roll-out of the vaccination campaign cannot begin until the first phase has been completed, in principle towards the end of March, subject to the delivery and availability of sufficient doses of vaccine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210810060408/https://msan.gouvernement.lu/en/actualites.gouvernement%2Ben%2Bactualites%2Btoutes_actualites%2Bcommuniques%2B2021%2B01-janvier%2B26-phase-2.html    **Phase 3 and Phase 4     The first invitations were sent to people under the age of 65, starting with the oldest, in line with the recommendations of the Superior Council for Infectious Diseases on 4 February 2021 concerning the conditions for administering the AstraZeneca vaccine. it is preferable to give preference to administering the BioNTech/Pfizer and Moderna mRNA vaccines to persons aged 65 and over, and to offer vaccination with the AstraZeneca vaccine to younger persons.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210810070049/https://msan.gouvernement.lu/en/actualites.gouvernement%2Ben%2Bactualites%2Btoutes_actualites%2Bcommuniques%2B2021%2B03-mars%2B02-vaccin-phase-5.html    ** Other high contact professionals such as disabled care home staff

Since 15 January 2022, the 3G CovidCheck system applies in the workplace (private and public sector). The staff or manager of restaurants, bars and cafes are subject to the "3G" system.  https://archive.ph/Tgtx6
See note C4.

For gatherings of up to 10 people, there are no restrictions or health measures to be observed.  For gatherings of 11 to 20 people (inclusive), masks and a physical distance of 2 metres between people are mandatory, or the CovidCheck (2G+) system applies.   Gatherings of between 21 and 200 people (inclusive) are subject to the CovidCheck 2G+ system, or the requirement to wear a mask and be seated at a minimum distance of 2 metres. CovidCheck 2G+ means that each person over 12 years and 2 months of age must present a vaccination or recovery certificate. They must also undergo a test exempt vaccination within the last 180 days, booster vaccination or recovery certificate.   Gatherings of more than 200 people are prohibited, unless they are subject to a health protocol accepted in advance by the Health Directorate, which determines the health measures to be observed.   https://archive.ph/lgq7X

For any person, aged 12 years and 2 months or older, authorised to enter Luxembourg (regardless of nationality), it is compulsory to present, before boarding a flight to Luxembourg a vaccination certificate, recovery certificate or negative test result. https://archive.ph/UBRC9

The 3G system, which has been compulsory in the workplace since December 2021, will become optional again. If the 3G system is not retained by the company, the rules on meetings and gatherings apply (wearing a mask and respecting distance) as soon as the number of employees present at the same time in the same place exceeds 10 (e.g. office, conference room, canteen etc.). https://archive.ph/Dskgx

There are no restrictions on gatherings or events that take place in your private home. The CovidCheck disappears in private homes. The thresholds for gatherings are hereby amended as follows.  For gatherings  of up to 10 people, there are no restrictions or health measures to be observed  Gatherings of between 11 and 50 people (inclusive): if the gathering is not organised under the CovidCheck system, the double condition of wearing a mask and a minimum distance of 2 metres is compulsory  Gatherings of between 51 and 200 people (inclusive): if the gathering is not organised under the CovidCheck system, the triple condition of wearing a mask, being seated and keeping a minimum distance of 2 metres is compulsory  Gatherings of between 201 and 2,000 people are in principle subject to the CovidCheck system, if not to the triple condition of wearing a mask, being designated a seat and keeping a minimum distance of 2 metres  Over 2,000 people, gatherings are authorised provided they are subject to a health protocol to be accepted in advance by the Health Directorate  The provisions regarding sports and cultural activities have been adapted to reflect the reintroduction of the 3G system. This system applies as soon as the number of people in the group exceeds 10.  https://archive.ph/Dskgx
The 2G+ system is replaced by the 3G system.  See note C3. https://archive.ph/8tcZ5 https://archive.ph/Dskgx

On January 22, a joint press conference by the WHO and Mongolia's Ministry of Health stated that 6 people with symptoms of flu arrived from Hong Kong and India at Chinggis Khaan airport and are being isolated and examined. Press conferences by the Ministry of Health continue to be regularly streamed on YouTube and Facebook.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628020244/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JeSpZYzRDVM https://web.archive.org/web/20210628021722/https://covid19.mohs.mn/p/cat/post/46/?page=20 https://web.archive.org/web/20210627233652/https://news.mn/en/790582/

On January 22, a joint press conference was held by the WHO and the Mongolia Ministry of Health. In Mongolia, 6 people with symptoms of flu arrived from Hong Kong and India at Chinggis Khaan airport; as a precaution they were isolated and examined. The people in question were diagnosed with normal flu viruses: Type A and B.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210627233652/https://news.mn/en/790582/

"The use of masks, especially from early November when flu season starts and air pollution worsens, is already familiar to Mongolians. However, from January 25, the capital city of Ulaanbaatar’s authorities demanded all employees at government offices, banks, shops, and markets wear masks. At the same time, public health professionals and community leaders conveyed the importance of mask wearing and hand-washing and worked to increase sanitation at all major urban centres and public places. The State Emergency Commission began promoting on April 13 a month-long campaign – “Let’s Wear Masks” – and implemented C$75 fines for those not wearing masks in public places. The government’s policy of requiring everyone to wear a mask seems to have also been effective in constraining habits like spitting in public and face touching, further reducing the close-contact spread of the virus." https://web.archive.org/web/20200819195813/https://www.asiapacific.ca/publication/mongolias-effective-analogue-approach-covid-19-containment   "Almost all the public spaces, starting with the malls and pharmacies, still require masks. But we realize that in the rural areas, wearing a mask every day is not possible."  https://archive.vn/kISVU

The State Emergency Commission decided to close all schools and kindergartens in the country from January 27, 2020 to March 2, 2020. This decision was later extended to April 30. [https://web.archive.org/web/20200413130551/https://montsame.mn/en/read/213965]  [http://web.archive.org/web/20200404101529/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse] [http://web.archive.org/web/20200413131109/https://eeas.europa.eu/headquarters/headquarters-homepage/77102/coronavirus-update-6-april-mongolia_en]

A ban on the operations of monasteries, churches, bars and nightclubs, sauna, motels and a varying degree of sports and cultural entities such as yoga, dance clubs and tourism remain in effect until March 30. The restaurants that do remain open in the city are on a mandatory 10 p.m. closing schedule. Public trading centers that have been closed since March 10, such as the local-favorite Black Market, are reopened on 16th March. http://web.archive.org/web/20200404103344/https://www.forbes.com/sites/breannawilson/2020/03/16/mongolia-announces-3-new-covid-19-cases-totaling-4-how-they-got-coronavirus-precautions-right/ Public places such as gaming centres have been shut until further notice. http://web.archive.org/web/20200404095732/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/315326/mongolia-government-extends-school-closures-until-march-30-due-to-coronavirus-update-2 Closure of city administration cultural offices, e.g. libraries, museums, and community and cultural centers until April 30. Closure of schools, universities, cinemas and entertainment centers until April 30. Closure of bars and reduction of the operating hours of restaurants until April 30. https://web.archive.org/web/20200410103705/https://mn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/ Some mining operations are closed https://web.archive.org/web/20200410115425/https://www.mining-technology.com/mining-safety/rio-tinto-mongolia-coronavirus

Public events including conferences, sports, and entertainment events have been prohibited. Public places such as gaming centres have been shut until further notice. http://web.archive.org/web/20200404095732/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/315326/mongolia-government-extends-school-closures-until-march-30-due-to-coronavirus-update-2   All public events and gatherings through the upcoming weeks were now canceled, a major challenge with one of the most celebrated holidays of the year, Tsagaan Sar, or Mongolian Lunar New Year, quickly approaching in February. During the period, Mongolia has also cancelled all sports competitions, training, seminars, cultural festivals and public events.  Most other businesses are functioning as usual.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210628013153/https://news.mn/en/790648/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628014314/https://news.mn/en/790992/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210629010129/https://thediplomat.com/2020/02/mongolia-braces-for-coronavirus-impact/

Since 27 January 2020, schools and universities have been closed and children are prohibited from public places such as shopping malls and restaurants until 30 March 2020 due to COVID-19 concerns.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210629003844/https://www.idlo.int/fr/news/notes-from-the-field/rule-law-time-covid-19-mongolia  https://web.archive.org/web/20200320035852/https://mn.usembassy.gov/security-alert-travel-restrictions-expanded-by-mongolian-government-in-response-to-corona-virus-covid-19-02-25-2020/

Borders with China have been closed to foot and vehicle traffic since Monday, January 27. The Mongolian government announced on Friday, January 31, that it will close Mongolia's borders to all Chinese citizens and foreigners traveling from China from Saturday, February 1, through Monday, March 2. The travel restriction will apply to individuals traveling via air, rail, and road. Mongolians will also be prohibited from traveling to China from February 1 through March 2. After February 6, Mongolians in China will only be allowed to return via Ulaanbaatar's Chinggis Khaan International airport (ULN) or the Zamiin Uud rail border. As of Tuesday, February 18, 336 Mongolian citizens remain in China seeking to return home. http://web.archive.org/web/20200404095732/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/315326/mongolia-government-extends-school-closures-until-march-30-due-to-coronavirus-update-2

As of January 28, Mongolia has detected no confirmed cases of COVID-19. All 29 suspected people who returned from China have been carefully checked: 14 of them were coronavirus negative, however, 13 people are still under observation at the National Centre for Communicable Diseases.  Mongolia received a total of 200 laboratory tests from Japan to detect the coronavirus infection. As of January 28, a total of 1966 people returned to Mongolia through the border crossings in the six southern provinces since Cabinet decided to close border crossings for pedestrian and vehicles, and before they were totally closed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210628022852/https://news.mn/en/790674/

It was announced on February 19 that roads and other forms of transportation would be suspended or blocked over Tsagaan Sar (February 21-27) across six provinces to further enforce the need to self-isolate and not gather in large groups. A necessary action to keep the flow of movement limited over a holiday that holds significance in the country. Prior to the ban, traffic into Ulaanbaatar was monitored by stopping cars and requiring that all passengers have their foreheads scanned to detect an abnormal temperature. Something I myself experienced.  But not all public transportation was banned, within the capital the main bus lines were running, but were limited to running on “peak” hours. And even though in the U.S. the CDC advises that wearing a face mask isn’t necessary if you are not sick, they were mandatory while riding public transportation in Ulaanbaatar. http://web.archive.org/web/20200404103344/https://www.forbes.com/sites/breannawilson/2020/03/16/mongolia-announces-3-new-covid-19-cases-totaling-4-how-they-got-coronavirus-precautions-right/

roads and other forms of transportation would be suspended or blocked over Tsagaan Sar (February 21-27) across six provinces. They actually stayed closed until March 16th http://web.archive.org/web/20200404103344/https://www.forbes.com/sites/breannawilson/2020/03/16/mongolia-announces-3-new-covid-19-cases-totaling-4-how-they-got-coronavirus-precautions-right/

Per the decision made at the State Emergency Commission meeting on March 1, the movement has been opened from March 3. In connection with the confirmed imported case of the novel coronavirus or Covid-19 in Mongolia, the Emergency Commission of Ulaanbaatar city decided to shut down following service centers and shops in the capital city until March 16, Monday.  All types of retail stores selling products other than grocery and products for household usage and their delivery services /Including all units of shopping malls, department stores and market places that are not selling groceries and household products. All types of food delivery services. All kinds of service centers except public showers /Including hair and beauty salons, tailor, shoe salons, dry cleaning services, all kinds of repair shops and services, photo printing, and moving services. Auto repair shops, auto service and retail stores, except tire repair shops. All types of quick service places, except the points selling ‘Smart Card’ bus passes. Restaurants, cafes, fast food restaurants, cafeterias and other eating places will remain operating with reduced hours until 10 PM every day.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210629010610/https://www.montsame.mn/en/read/218413

https://web.archive.org/web/20200511150059/https://thediplomat.com/2020/05/practice-makes-perfect-mongolias-covid-19-outbreak-drill/  “the Mongolian government conducted a three-day drill to check the response and coordination between 14 local and national organizations during a simulated COVID-19 outbreak. The drill started on May 5 with a hypothetical scenario, during which a routine test of the local population revealed three people in the Chingeltei district to be infected with COVID-19.”  “The drill started on May 5 with a hypothetical scenario, during which a routine test of the local population revealed three people in the Chingeltei district to be infected with COVID-19. The next day, on May 6, local law enforcement together with doctors started to check all the people who were in direct contact with the three sick patients. During the investigation it was revealed that hundreds of people had become sick (again, for the purposes of the simulated drill scenario).  Phase two of the drill started with cordoning off the whole Chingeltei district to stop the spread of the virus to other parts of the city. During the exercise, all citizens were urged to not go outside unless required for medical reasons. Three medical facilities were set up to specifically deal with simulated COVID-19 patients.”

Although the government has decided to not restrict internal movement, it is nonetheless continuing with tracing the in and out flows on the checkpoints placed at 6 major checkpoints around the city of Ulaanbaatar (Emeelt, Baruunturuun, Gunt, Ulziit, Morin and Nalaikh)     Ulaanbaatar is by far the biggest urban settlement in Mongolia concentrating almost half of the country’s population. It is a major destination, transition point and origin for population movements and as such may represent a powerful source for spreading COVID-19 to the entire country. To increase its preparedness and also an eventual response to COVID-19, the Governor’s Office of the Capital City has requested the assistance of International Organization for Migration, Mission to Mongolia (IOM) to take evidence of all the incoming and outgoing flows of people by implementing its Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) methodology. This is expected to last until June 1st.     https://web.archive.org/web/20200517020615/https://reliefweb.int/report/mongolia/mongolia-flow-monitoring-ulaanbaatar-covid-19-preparedness-situation-report-66-4-may

Government on 2 Aug on how it is using international aid:  "For example, the child allowance was increased to MNT 100,000, funding for food purchases for low-income families was doubled, MNT 73,000 was provided to 73,000 people from 6.9 thousand low-income enterprises, and social welfare pensioners and permanent care recipients were provided. An additional MNT 768 billion has been spent so far, including an increase of MNT 100,000 in child benefits.  In addition, in order to protect the income of citizens, business entities and organizations, a total of 1 trillion 877.9 billion MNT of social insurance premiums, personal income and corporate income tax, its interest and fines were completely exempted. The Kovid-19 epidemic has created a total budget burden of 2.5 trillion MNT. "  http://archive.fo/E0dVy

Mongolian authorities responded to the confirmation of the country's first locally transmitted coronavirus disease (COVID-19) case on Wednesday, November 11, by ordering a five-day nationwide lockdown from 06:00 (local time) on Thursday, November 12, through to 06:00 on Tuesday, November 17.  Residents will only be able to leave home to purchase essential goods or attend work if they are unable to work from home.   Link: https://archive.vn/78Bce

Mongolia has ended a lockdown in several provinces, including the capital Ulaanbaatar.  Meanwhile, 'Battsengel soum in Arkhangai and Altanbulag and Sukhbaatar soums in Selenge are subject to more severe restrictions until at least 21 December under a state of “all-out readiness”. The public in those locations need to avoid any non-essential activities and movement. Essential services such as grocery stores, pharmacies and hospitals remain open.  The government of Mongolia has placed all other provinces in Mongolia under a state of “high alert”, which entails less severe restrictions.'    https://archive.vn/AcMHj

Authorities will ease restrictions nationwide from 06:00 May 8 amid ongoing COVID-19 activity. Officials will permit most business sectors to resume operations; however, higher-risk businesses, such as retail outlets, cultural and entertainment venues, fitness facilities, bars, and nightclubs, will remain closed until at least May 22. Restaurants cannot offer dine-in services, though some outdoor seating is possible.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210510021011/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/475396/mongolia-officials-plan-to-ease-restrictions-nationwide-from-0600-may-8-update-23

"Sultanate of Oman has announced it is placing Muscat under total lockdown for 12 days, as of Friday, Oman News Agency reported on Wednesday.    The move is part of the Sultanate’s intensive efforts and precautionary measures to contain the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic.    (...) The ministry reiterated its calls on the public to adhere to the precautionary measures and home quarantine instructions. It urged everyone to adhere strictly to social distancing instructions issued by the Supreme Committee as well as to stay at home and not go out unless necessary."    Source: https://archive.vn/eF6do#selection-2891.7-2923.213

15 April  In Oman two crises are occurring; COVID 19 Outbreak, and dropping oil prices. Expatriates make up around 50% of the population of around 4 million people.  “On 15th April 2020 the Supreme Committee for Covid-19 in the Sultanate of Oman issued a statement in relation to a comprehensive economic measures package designed to bolster the private sector firms and its Omani workers. Clauses include:  Give paid leave with full salary to workers during the period of health isolation and Stay-at-Home period provided a “certificate on the end of quarantine period” be issued by the departments concerned.  Non-termination of services of Omani manpower.  Non-Omani manpower: Their respective employees’ annual leave may be advanced and paid in full if they operate in the sectors terminally shut down.  Non-Omani manpower: Expatriate workers of affected private sector establishments and firms can be terminally repatriated to their respective countries, according to the package agreed by the Supreme Committee and establishments and firms of the private sector.  Oman News Agency Source: http://archive.vn/eXq4q  Law Website Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200702122305/https://www.cms-lawnow.com/ealerts/2020/04/oman-responds-to-covid19-with-economic-stimulus-package-to-bolster-the-private-sector  Clyde and Co Company Source:http://archive.vn/hAlqs  Time of Oman Media Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200503033146/https://timesofoman.com/article/3013838/oman/government/coronavirus-supreme-committee-issues-new-decisions  NOTE ****Declared from April until June 30th 2020. I have coded as a 2, for replacing over 50% of lost salary, and 0 for private and formal sector workers as no mention is made for the public or informal sector here.****

A statement issued online by the Government Communication Centre (GC) said, "The conditions for wearing a mask outside the home are as follows: Once a person leaves the house, he must wear a mask. This includes at all permitted commercial and industrial activities and workplaces in the public and private sectors, public transportation and other public places.”    The statement confirmed: “All should wear masks while driving their own vehicles. Wearing the mask inside the vehicle depends on the following cases: If the driver of the vehicle is alone, he is not obligated to wear it, but he is obligated to wear it when he exits the vehicle. If the driver of the vehicle is with his family members inside the vehicle, everyone is not obligated to wear it inside the vehicle, but if someone exits from the vehicle, they must wear a mask.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20200921143406/https://www.zawya.com/mena/en/legal/story/ROP_clarifies_conditions_for_wearing_masks_in_Oman-SNG_175327867/

The Gulf state will also implement a daily curfew from 7 p.m. to 6 a.m. during the period, which includes the Muslim Eid al-Adha holiday period. Since Dhofar governorate was still on under lockdown and the country-wide lockdown is between governorates - and not a stay at home requirement (curfew) -  a T flag (instead of G) was chosen.    Review Note: Changed to 3G from 3T because the country was under curfew during this period. As of 18th August 2020, Oman's Supreme Committee announced today the fifth batch of businesses are allowed to open now, while adhering to the COVID-19 precautions. Muttrah souq, a bustling market place for traditional and modern wares that had been closed for some time, will now be open.  Other businesses that will be open are restaurants, gyms and swimming pools inside hotel establishments, fish markets across all governorates, commercial activities that are run inside traditional markets, newspaper and magazine printing, special training activities approved by the Ministry of Manpower, playgrounds for the purpose of training national teams for regional and international events to be used by the national football team, national junior team, Oman national futsal team, Dhofar sports club, tennis playground for the general category, sale of phone sim cards, car wash centres, sale of tobacco and its products, tents’ sale and tailoring shops.    Even though the international and tourists restaurants are allowed to open, sale of shisha and alcoholic drinks are not allowed to be served. The Sultanate of Oman has instituted its first unemployment insurance scheme, through a royal decree. Decree No.82/2020, signed by His Majesty Sultan Haitham bin Tarik Al Said on 17 August, legally institutes the Public Authority for Social Insurance (PASI)’s Employment Security Scheme for all Omani workers in the public, private, military and security sectors. The scheme will come into force on 1 November.'  “It has been demonstrated by countries in the region that unemployment and wage protection benefits are essential in responding to the economic shocks caused by COVID-19. The new scheme will provide much needed support to workers whose income earnings are at risk with the current pandemic and related economic crisis,” Pellerano continued.  The new scheme will provide temporary income support to insured Omanis who lost their employment involuntarily and who seek to become reemployed.   The new scheme will provide temporary income support to insured Omanis who lost their employment involuntarily and who seek to become reemployed. It will be the first ever scheme in Oman to cover all Omani workers, be they in the private, public, military or security sectors, under one fund, and the benefit will be linked with active labour market policies. Unemployed insured Omanis will be entitled to receive benefits upon the first claim, provided that they have been affiliated with the scheme for 12 consecutive months - or for 12 non- consecutive months over a period of 36 months - prior to unemployment. However, this entitlement condition will be waived for the first year of the scheme.     Benefits will be paid monthly for six consecutive or non-consecutive months and amount to 60 per cent of the average salary paid during the 24 months prior to unemployment, provided that the value of the benefit shall not be less than the minimum pension provided in the social security law.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210411212435/https://www.ilo.org/beirut/media-centre/news/WCMS_758289/lang--en/index.htm

A:    27 December  Dubai: Oman has launched a national COVID-19 vaccination campaign, with the sultanate’s health minister receiving the first dose of the Pfizer vaccine, local media reported.  State-run media reported that the first batch of 15,600 doses was flown in industrial freezers to Muscat International Airport last week to vaccinate a priority group of older adults, health care workers and those with underlying health conditions starting on Sunday (27 December).    The Health Ministry said the initial phase of the vaccination campaign would cover 20 percent of the population due to temporarily limited supply.    During the early stages of vaccine distribution, priority to develop immunity from COVID-19 will be given to those working on the frontline,” - therefore despite intentions to vaccinate more groups, have coded just one until further evidence emerges    https://web.archive.org/web/20210108103954/https://gulfnews.com/world/gulf/oman/oman-launches-national-covid-19-vaccine-campaign-1.76136737     https://web.archive.org/web/20210118143949/https://www.hoteliermiddleeast.com/news/121645-oman-to-offer-covid-19-vaccine-from-december-27

From December 27, 2021, the first phase of vaccination rollout begun targeting groups in community including the elderly 65 years of age and above with diabetes, those with kidney failure and who are on dialysis, those with chronic lung diseases including Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), Asthma (with a disease severity ranging between moderate to severe) and Interstitial lung disease (ILD), as well as targeting groups of healthcare workers including ICU staff, staff working in COVID-19 wards and those healthcare employees who have any of the following: diabetes, obesity (BMI more than or equal to 40), being on dialysis, chronic lung disease as detailed in the target groups in community.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210801101254/https://www.moh.gov.om/documents/10194/4652109/Q%26A+about+covid+19+vaccine.pdf/16df6246-440a-6cca-dc58-5cd3672b9f03  https://web.archive.org/web/20210801171143/https://platform.twitter.com/widgets/widget_iframe.0504c5db6e58d499a7ba93c246a8554d.html?origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.arabnews.com

"It is not allowed to enter the Musandam Governorate except for those who have received at least one dose of the vaccine approved in the Sultanate (those who are 18 years old and over) of citizens and residents in the Sultanate, and for those who have received two doses of the approved vaccine for those coming from outside the Sultanate, starting from five o’clock from On the evening of Friday 28 Dhu al-Qa’dah 1442 AH corresponding to July 9, 2021 AD until further notice."     "With the advent of the monsoon season in the Governorate of Dhofar (Khareef), citizens and residents of the Sultanate who have received at least one dose of the vaccine approved in the Sultanate (those aged 18 years and over) can enter the Governorate of Dhofar, and it is also allowed to enter the governorate for those who received two doses of the vaccine. Omani citizens, residents with valid residency permits, and travelers with a valid visa are allowed to enter the Sultanate without prior approval. To maintain the health service department’s ability to handle the situation, the Covid-19 Supreme Committee took the following decisions, which will be enforced for a period of two weeks with effect from Sunday 23 January:    Firstly, limiting to 50 per cent  the number of employees who attend at the workplace in units of the State’s Administrative Apparatus (government units) and other public entities.    Secondly, suspending all conferences and exhibitions.    Thirdly, suspending congregational activities and advising the organisers to hold them without audience, while at the same time ensuring that the participants/organisers abide by the precautionary measures announced before, including showing proof of vaccination.    Fourthly, suspending the holding of Friday prayers, while at the same time allowing mosques to hold the five daily prayers at a capacity of 50 percent  at each mosque and in line with the procedures announced by the Ministry of Endowments and Religious Affairs in coordination with the Ministry of Health.    https://archive.vn/g0Dm0

03/07/2022    Effective February 21, 2022,   passengers traveling to the Sultanate are no longer required to register with the Ministry of Health (https://travel.moh.gov.om/).    Effective March 01, 2022,   a negative COVID19 PCR test is no longer required for the entry of fully vaccinated travelers aged 18 and older. Non-citizen travelers aged 18 and above traveling to the Sultanate of Oman are required to present a vaccination certificate indicating that they have received at least two doses of a Sultanate-approved COVID19 vaccine at least 14 days before traveling.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307060955/https://om.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
